reviewText:
NOT A PRE-RELEASE REVIEW

This is one of my favorite alpha games ever to hit Steam.. And It's a damn shame I have to stomp it into the ground because during the estimated 1-2 years of work I expected this game to take before beginning to reach a finished state, the developers had a stroke of genius and decided that it would be a good idea to call this HEAVY ALPHA GAME a FULLY RELEASED TITLE after being on Steam for only 5-6 months. Doing so, Avalanche Studios have yet again showed the world that they do not give a damn about actually delivering a polished product to customers and fans alike and instead falsely advertise & release yet another unfinished glitch-fest onto Steam like a big, flaccid díck onto your dinner table, expecting a price-tag of 30€ for an experience you can expect out of a glitchy tech demo.

I mean holy hell. They JUST spewed out a new dinosaur with this release update".. AND IT HAS NO TESTING DONE TO IT WHATSOEVER. If you still insist on buying this garbage

reviewText:
===ANOTHER UPDATE===
The birds are completely fixed now and no longer pick you up and drop you from a height and kill you. They'll only do that now when you're on low health so it's much better.

The game has improved since my last update, the triceratops now act like rhinos instead of deer which is much better.


===UPDATE===
They've updated the birds and the game is once again enjoyable as long as you stay away from the volcano (where the birds spawn).

But I still stand by my comments about it not being a release spec game, this is still the quality of an early access game by far.

========================================

REVIEW ON FIRST DAY OF RELEASE:

In early access this game was brilliant. On release however, they added the new flying dino with a strange name which I can't remember...

The new species has ruined the balance of the game, it'd been added with little to no thought whatsoever. It's a rushed release. In it's current state, I would not buy the game. I won't be playing it in it's current state either. The game used to be challenging but enjoyable, now it's overly challenging with you dying 10 times an hour and eventually rage quitting with nothing enjoyable about it. I'd rather take on a T-Rex than the over powered birds. With a T-Rex, you can hear it, you can see it coming, you have a chance. These birds, you'll probably shoot it once it'll grab you and drop you from a height and you die and there's nothing you can do about it.

There are still crashes, tons of glitches, this is no where near a release spec" game. Don't buy the game unless they've updated it and fixed the above."

reviewText:
While the concept behind this game has potential, the developers seem to have abandoned the development. It feels very empty, perdictable, and lacking features you would expect in this kind of game. The devs expressed to the players that they will develop this game over time, yet that has not been the case at all. The only update I have seen in the several months I have owned it is a few rare dino skins; hardly a feature to make it worth waiting for updates for.

As with others that have reviewed this game, it seems like the devs have baited players to purchase this game, only to use the funds to continue work on their free-to-play conterpart: The Hunter.

I must say that until the devs actually commit resources to further development, I cannot, and do not recommend this game to ANYONE!

reviewText:
God d****t, god f*****g d****t it happened again.

Another product not ready for release. D':

[EDIT3]: I would like to update this review to address some of the points brought up by some reviewers who have thumbed up this game:

1) People who thumb down this game are little kids who just want call of duty can can't handle the difficulty of this game.
My response: Um, hello? Have you been playing this game?  It's seriously ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly easy now.  I have no idea what you are talking about.  Yes, things used to be very dangerous, you used to have to actually hunt, but now you can just run full speed through the forest and if anything comes at you all you have to do is step to the side or next to a rock and because of the crappy pathing you can just blow anything away COD stye.  Let me just say for those that have not yet bought this game, anyone who makes this argument has no idea what they are talking about.  I mean seriously, there's one guy on here with like 500 hours on this game saying that . . . 500 ♥♥♥♥ing hours . . . 500 ♥♥♥♥ING HOURS! 500 ♥♥♥♥ING HOURS IN A ♥♥♥♥ING HALF BAKED EARLY ACCESS WITH 5 ♥♥♥♥ING DINOSAURS THAT PRETTY MUCH JUST RANDOMLY WALK AROUND!  500 ♥♥♥♥ING HOURS!!!! ARE YOU ♥♥♥♥ING KIDDING ME?!?!  I PLAYED THE ♥♥♥♥ OUT OF SKYRIM WITH LIKE A BILLION CHARACTERS, WEAPONS, QUESTS, ETC. AND I COULD ONLY DO 300 HOURS AND YOU'RE ♥♥♥♥ING TELLING ME YOU PUT IN 500 ♥♥♥♥ING HOURS WITH LIKE A FEW ♥♥♥♥ING  WEAPONS AND 5 ♥♥♥♥ING DINOSAURS THAT ALMOST DO ♥♥♥♥ING NOTHING.  This game is not ♥♥♥♥ing better than my beloved Skyrim.  Don't waste your money.

2) Yeah they shouldn't have released this game and yeah they messed up on the release update but they are trying to fix it so everything will be ok.
My response: I think you are delusional. :p  They are trying to fix the update because they haven't gotten any money because of all the negative reviews.  That is the only reason they have responded.  So let me explain what's really going on.  This is a cash grab.  The developers are trying to pull a fast one on us by making this very flashy appearing game that we have all been desiring for a long time, make it barely playable, release it as a full game, and rake in the doe as people buy this game thinking its something it's not.  They know exactly what they are doing and there will be nothing further added on to the game once they make it playable again after those f****** birds.  Furethermore, even if they fix the game from the update that's not the problem, the problem is that they are trying to rip us off by trying to make this whole debacule ok.  Well it's not ok babe.  So for those who haven't bought this yet, don't waste your money.

Chasing the early access dragon never pays off; I swear I will never do early access again.

[EDIT]:  I hope this is an April fools joke.

[EDIT2]: Nope not an April fools joke. Also, this is not a pre-release review!

I just don't understand, this game has so much potential, it is so awesome even when it was early access.  Why release it now when it clearly is alpha?

So let me go through some of the clear issues real fast:
1) As another review said, they just released a new dinosaur. . . untested. . .
2) The entire island is made of predators (except the triceratops) . . .
3) There are no interaction between dinosaurs (no t-rex eating raptors etc.)
4) you can easily step to the side and are invulnerable to the raptors due to primitive pathing.
5) AI in general is meh.  Dinosarus just walk around aimlessly until they sense a player and either run away or run towards them.  Sometimes you might be hunted by a raptor which is cool right up til you simply step to the side and blow him away cause he's a complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥.
6) No real survival mechanics despite the claim in the discription.  As far as survival mechanics go, you just get weapons and shoot at poorly AI driven lizards.
7) Sounds have no direction so you cannot tell where the dinosaurs are comming from.  You just know they are somewhere around you.
8) Primitive hunting mechanics that are not explained at all.  There's cammo you can find but I'm not sure it actually does anything, nothing with smells as far as I can tell, and sounds are a factor but are prone to glitches.  A.k.a. it is impossible to hide from a T-Rex.  You can track dinosaurs and there is sign but it's obvious, takes no real effort, and your gps does all the work somehow for you.
9) The characters look like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hipsters who have some fetish for taking weird selfies with whatever they've managed to kill on this island. DX  Makes me want to get eaten.
10) There are so many things that obvously need to be put into the game for a full release but aren't its seriously depressing.  I mean this game could be good, like really really good.

Basically I would recommend this game if and only if it was put back into early access and reasonably regular updates happened over the course of a year or two.  That is what we all expected and were happy with.  I mean seriously I'm perfectly fine with a game taking time to develop as long as reasonable progress is made.

While this game has amazing potential, I cannot in good faith recommend it because it is alpha and should NOT be considered a full release.

[EDIT]: And these god d**n birds have ruined everything.  Seriously I'm pretty sure this release is an early April fools joke because this is ridiculous.  I mean seriously unbelieveable.  If it is just a joke I will update this review to a recommend.

[EDIT2]: Nope not April fools joke.  And you know what the worst part is?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In laymans terms, this game mixes the Carnivores experience with a survival aspect. I found myself listening very closely for cues about nearby dinosaurs, as well as looking for dangerous foliage. The sound in this game is so excellent, it's hard to describe in words.

This is one of the few dinosaur games in a long time that feels 'serious', in my opinion. There are a fair share of bugs (rubberbanding dinosaurs, some collision issues), but for 85% of the game, you more than likely wont notice an issue.

This game fills a void that I have been longing to satiate for years. Highly recommended!

Check out the video for a hands-on look (no terrible BG music or lame voiceovers, I promise!)
http://www.twitch.tv/gamethesison/b/599497190

EDIT: I'll leave this anecdotal part here

5 minutes in, a Tyrannosaur charged me, drug me down a mountain, and feasted on my body. 10/10 would die again

This game is absolutley terrible, it is underdeveloped, unplanned and was obviously just a quick scheme to get some funds for the company.

The IDEA for the game was good, and I really tied to like it, but the application was horrific (I'm listing 10 reasons below)

reviewText:
Me and this guy were walking around and saw a T-Rex, so we went prone. The giant god damn reptile walked right over us while we were laying there ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ our pants. When we thought we were safe, we slowly crawled away. After a few seconds passed, I heard a screen shaking, eardrum popping, massive sounding roar as I turned around to see my friend get devoured by a reptillian Satan. The beast then looked to me. We locked eyes for a moment, and a sense of understanding moved through me. It was then that the beast moved unto me, roared in my face, and ate me.



10/10, would die again.


But now for an actual review.

After puting an extensive amount of time playing the game, I feel that I am ready to give a completely honest and full fledged review. This game, at its core, is very hit or miss. Some people will love it, while others will instantly denounce it for being too hard or a cash grab. While I believe the game is well worth the money, don't take my word for it. I will attempt to give the pros and cons of the game in a completely unbiased fashion, so that you may form your own opinion about the game before you buy it.

PROS:
1. World and Atmosphere. This game couples amazing sound design with stunning visuals creates an amazing immersive world. You can hear T-Rexes stomping around from miles away, and spot Quezalcoatluses flying in the sky before they have a chance to see you. While this does add to the immersion, it also rewards attentive players who can see a threat before it even knows they exist.

2. Weapons and Damage Models. The weapons of Primal are very grounded in reality. All weapons match to their respective ammunition types and every weapon looks, sounds, and feels like an actual weapon. Firearms are loud, bows have believable ballistics, and everything feels very solid. Coming from someone who is very experienced with firearms, I can attest to the realism of this game's weapons. Also, being based on a realistic hunting game, Primal's damage models are very precise. Heart shots are king, while general body/gut shots will not instantly drop most of Primal's beasts. Overall, the guns are good.

3. The Actual Gameplay. Primal's gameplay is very intense, You can go from walking through a peaceful field to being chased by Utahraptors in mere seconds. This isn't a casual game. Deaths are punishing while kills are immensly rewarding. Even with high level gear, carelessness is often punished with death.


CONS:
1. Bugs. While the games stability has been immensely improved, the game still has lots of bugs. It wil crash every so often, and movement is very finicky. Also, the only servers are hosted through other player's internet connections, resulting in high pings and short lived servers.

2. Developement. Until recently, this game had been declared dead by most. The developers of this game are very invested in other projects and seem to view Primal of a sort of hobby on the side. On the up side, they have issued a survey for players to take and have also decided to try and tackle some of the bugs. Even though the game has officially released, they still intend on giving it regular updates.


CONSENSUS: Primal is a great concept, but it is still in the making. While basic gameplay is good, there are still things that need to be ironed out and content that should be added in. While I understand some negative reviews, I believe that many of them portray this game in a bad light. Many people simply expect things from the game that it simply cannot offer. There isn't crafting or base building (as of yet) because the game is developed and marketed as a dinosaur hunting game. But, in the end, it is for you to decide. If you enjoy challenging or intense games, this is for you. If you're looking for another Primal Carnage of Orion: Prelude, then you will be dissapointed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I Alt-F4'd as a Tyrannosaur sprinted towards me.   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m5Gs15Y7UN8

Full Review:

Now that I have at least an hour under my belt, my initial impressions are as follows:

Pros:

1) Superb Sound design and stage. The forests and wildlife sound authentic, and the dinosaurs don't use recycled soundbytes from other games/movies.

2) Graphical fidelity is great, but it's nothing to write home about.

3) The difficulty is refreshing and adds a feeling of helplessness as you're pursued by otherworldy creatures.

4) Based on the developer's track record, this game won't be abandonded. I'm looking at you, The Stomping Land.

Cons:

1) It's immediately clear that this isn't a finished product and requires more content. In most instances the game will spawn you next to one of the three available dinosaurs, which loses its charm after being mauled several times.

2) I haven't been able to host or join multiplayer sessions. This will most likely be patched within the coming days before Christmas.

3) Key-Binding seems to be a bit unorthodox. I found myself rebinding most of the default keys to more comfortable orientations to suit my casual play-style.

4) Odd instances of AI-behavior and glitches. Despite being well-hidden, dinosaurs are inclined to walk directly towards you and into your line of sight; I also died in a pond reaching only my thighs.

5) The Island is very large, but it still lacks a great deal of polish. More folliage and natural landscaping would do wonders for this game.


Final thoughts:
If you're thinking of picking up this game, wait until more content is introduced. Ultimately, I picked this up as a future investment, and because I just love me some dinah-saours. Consider this a future recommendation.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As an expert in the field of paleontology I have a vast knowledge of dinosaurs, in particular the velociraptor; so therefore, I feel that I am in a strong position to express my thoughts on the hunting grounds of Primal Eden.

I arrived on this planet having agreed to fly over it for a small fee as a tour guide (of some sort). At no point did I believe that these people were remotely crazy enough to land the plane. I woke up on an abandoned runway having been knocked out via a blow to the head. The distant sound of a man and woman shouting at the top of their voices filled my entire body with dread and fear as I came around. I knew this was now a fight for survival!

As I moved swiftly and quietly through the thick, dense and foggy bush I hoped that I would find signs of life such as camps left over by previous people who dared venture to this ludicrous planet. Perhaps I could find some sort of radio or telephone that I could use to call for help. By now the valley around me filled with the unnerving sounds of various carnivores. The roars piercing my heart and sending tremors straight through my spine. There was no hope.

As I laid helplessly in a thick set plant I felt the horrifying thud as the ground started to shake. I then realised it was the same terror I had experienced some years ago in Jurassic Park. The thunderous sound began to get louder and louder. I then ran as fast as my legs would allow over the valley hill and found an abandoned camp called Sir Arthur’s Folley. To my delight and amazement I found a .700 rifle and 2 bullets. I do not like guns but I intended to survive this island as I have done twice previously. As I loaded the bullets the tyrannosaurus rex came crashing through the trees behind me…...I knew what had to be done.

I tried to throw a stone to distract the foul beast but to no avail. His head raised into the air as he then let of a rambunctious growl before charging at me. I immediately ran behind one the compounds concrete walls in fear of what was about to happen, with adrenaline pumping around my body I looked around the wall at the oncoming charge. I raised my rifle and shot the creature in the head! Nothing happened... I then ran back behind the wall where I realised my health was low from when I dropped down the small cliff into the camp. I sprayed myself with magic spray that made me feel revitalised and full of energy. The mighty head of the beast then clipped straight through the corner of the wall scaring the s**t out of me. “How the f**k can you do that” I angrily yelled at the beast. It then stood still so I took my shot, BANG, I hit the animal in the upper chest just below the neck. He let of an almighty howl as I punctured the left lung. As I aimed down the sight for one last time I pulled the trigger….nothing happened. I had no ammo.

I then thought LEG IT, so I ran down the hill until my stamina had deserted me. I laid down in a bush hoping the foul creature had not seen me. My heart was thumping and sweat was pouring from my entire body. The footsteps crashed down the hill behind me. I laid there motionless. The T Rex then stopped not knowing where I was. I had done it, I had got away from the beast when I then heard footsteps to my left. I looked to find a guy in a bright yellow shirt and orange trousers standing in my bush. I then slowly looked around at the T Rex as he then spotted me, charged me and then ate me. NOOOOOOOOO! The guy in yellow and orange clothes then proceeded to steal my gear and disappear into the night.

Hmmm, maybe I get into character a little too much when I play this game….It is an epic game especially when played with other people. Getting ambushed by raptors or five people running from two T Rex’s is sooo much fun! Awesome game that you must try.

reviewText:
Sorry to say, I'm very dissapointed with this game. I went in with high expectations, i mean after all, a survival game with Dinos? that sounds amazing! sad to say it was not.

Mainly, there isn't enough content. I can't believe they would call this finished. There are none of your typical survival game aspects in here at all. No base building, trap building, crafting, hunger, nothing.
You spend the whole game wandering this GIANT map, (which wouldnt be such an issue if you didnt walk slower than a crippled grandmother), trying to find supply boxes (which mind you, are NO WHERE near eachother) in order to defend yourself against near impossible to kill dinosaurs. Then, hopefully, if you manage to stay alive long enough, you can freely track and hunt the dinosaurs. Thats it. seriously, thats all.
Not to mention there are only a grand total of 5 dinosaurs in the game. all of which are carnivores. (minus the Triceratops) and if you get spoted by a Utahraptor, you are pretty much screwed. you have limited defense, and you can't run very far or fast. Its irritating.
The enviroment could use some cleaning up aswell. As much as they are beautiful, and perfect for screenshots and such, they aren't very functional for gameplay. most of the map has very steep hills, making it seem like the player shouldn't be there. Its very rocky, making it difficult to manuver. Most of the terrain is uneven, water clips through the beaches at places it shouldnt, the water randomly gets deep in some spots and seeing as you can't swim, also makes it hard to move across some beaches, and rivers/streams. Not to mention you can't jump.
You also cant carry very much, which becomes problematic, if you cant store your ammo anywhere. Especially when you usually spend mostof the game with far more ammo than weapons. (and more ammo for weapons you dont have)

Honestly, I'm very dissapointed. The idea for this game was great, but it's far from finished and is lacking severly in content. ESPECIALLY when they want $30 for it.

dont waste the money.

reviewText:
Update 4/11/2015:
They did a MAJOR overhaul on the Quetzalcoatlus and it made the game A LOT more bearable. Quetzalcoatlus aren't EVERYWHERE now (they only spawn near Volcano's and really high lands). This alone made the game so much better. Now you can actually EXPLORE the land without definite insta-death.

However, every other issue I've stated is still a thing.
1) You rarely see dinosaurs in a game about dinosaurs.
2) You travel for LOOOOONG lengths of time (up to 50mins) with absolutely nothing happening.
3) Killing dinosaurs is nigh impossible at the start of the game (i.e. Levels 1 through 5-ish)
4) If you haven't racked up a few kills for exp and money then good luck killing anything after an hour.

Once you get to higher levels (9+) the game becomes a lot more tolerable; but from a gamer point of view: Why would I want to keep playing a game if the start of it is dreadful, boring, and hard (in the sense that you can't really kill anything)? I mean, yes, the survival aspect becomes fun once you're higher level; but with that promise, why would a person new to the game stick around long enough to sift through the bane of this game?

I know I called the game Garbage" in my original review; but it's not. What it is
date: is unbearable (at first). And you'll have to put up with that unbearable irritation for a long time because levels aren't easy to gain (since dinos are rare to come across). Once you get past that

you could potentially start to enjoy yourself.

As many of you have noticed in the reviews on March 31, this game is finnaly out of its (quote)EARLY ACCESS(qoute) and I must say that it is terrabey unbalanced. reviewText:
Before we start, I want to be clear: You're enjoyment (and the relevance of this review) depends entirely on what you're expecting from TheHunter: Primal. If you are expecting a slow-burn, high tension survival title in an alien world of dinosaurs, you may garner a lot of enjoyment from this game.
If you are expecting a immersive, realistic hunting simulator where you pursue and down the greatest creatures to ever walk the land, you will probably be disappointed.

First, the positive: the game is beautiful. The textures are crisp. The dinosaurs are quite colourful and varied looking, yet still manage to blend in enough to require careful spotting. The plantlife is dense and oppressive. The weather is startling to see for the first time. The world is huge and packed with dense forests, open plains, beaches and swampland.

The dinosaur damage model is highly detailed, with careful shot placement required to ensure that Utahraptor goes down in one shot, or at least bleeds out before it runs too far to track the body.
The sound design is also well thought out, as careful listening is needed to pick up approaching predators and tell their mood.

What are the major problems with this game? The largest (in my opinion) is the stamina and running mechanics. I mentioned this game is huge. It truly is, yet you walk with the speed and haste of a high-class Victorian lady visiting the Botanic Gardens on Sunday afternoon. The stamina bar is woefully low and is depleted in 10-15 seconds of running (the running too is far slower than any person with full use of their legs would manage when being pursued by hungry dinos). It refills much slower than it is consumed. I can understand wanting to discourage endless running over kilometres without breaking a sweat, but for the self-proclaimed most realistic prehistoric survival game ever created"
recommended: not to mention immersion breaking. It also makes no sense from a standpoint of offering a challenge to players: most everything can outrun you if it makes a beeline for you

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Edit to precurser review: I would now recommend this game to anyone looking. While it is not all together in its current state, I have been in contact with the developers and they do have plans to continually update it with what the community wants. By purchasing this game, you show them that there is a market for it, and encourage them to better the game.

Here is a video to show some gameplay mechanics.... Don't judge too hard, this was only my 3rd time playing

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TX5V89qZgHs


Edit: Some more footage with the shotgun. Protip.... dont engage a T-Rex by yourself unless you have ungodly amounts of high powered ammo.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DoWonxvsZQM&feature=youtu.be


Pros:
-Awesome sounds
-Visually Stunning
-Massive map
-Stealth System

Cons
-some of the weapons are underpowered (will explain later)
-I have yet to kill a T-Rex. (May be a pro to some, but i put 8 slugs in ones heart/lung/brain.... plus 10 arrows in the lung region.... it should have died)
-To many dinosaurs (wouldnt be a problem if you could actually kill them)
-You move to slowly, and the stamina bar that allows you to run is depleted WAY to quickly, and recharges WAY to slowly. (seriously devs, go for a run, an average in-shape human can run alot farther than you imagine, and recover rather quickly)
-Only 3 dinos (Im sure they plan on adding more

Edit: After playing this game for  nearly 6 hours now, I wanted to redo this review. I still find some of the weapons to be underpowered coming from a real life point of view. Both the slug shotgun, and magnum handgun should be much more powerful than they are, but they provide a fun challenge. The hitboxes on the dinosuars are still a bit off IMO, however once you get the learning curve, you can get it with a bit of luck. It is pretty fun to explore the island and try to hunt or avoid being seen. The graphics are beautiful, and ive found myself stopping several times to enjoy the view. If this game continues to be updated, it will be great by the time it reaches full rollout!

Note for the devs:
I found a few bugs so far I wanted to report
-Tab doesnt always pull up pda
-Rebalance gun damage
-As long as a dino is behind you, it cannot hurt you
-when you create a new game it is not truely new, it also doesnt spawn you with anything half the time
-When you leave the game and come back, sometimes your secondary weapon is gone.

As the game progresses and updates are made I will change my rating and review, I will also have gameplay video up shortly that I will link.

Thanks for reading!


Edit 12/16/14: The developer contacted me confirming they had recieved my feedback and would be implementing several parts.I will be changing my recommendation to a thumbs up once the first update is out. As long as the devs will listen to the community and continue to put out updates, I will reccomend it. As I continue to play it, I enjoy it more and more. Of it still isnt fully there, but it is an enjoyable time waster. As of now there really is no objective, Im hoping some objective will be added later. Also another thing that I have found to be annoying is the fact that you cant stack  items. If you find a pile of 2 arrows, and one of 3 you cannot combine them. Once again im sure this will be fixed later.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Honest and non-misleading gameplay:
http://youtu.be/0Ecn1IITdjg

Comparing this to The Stomping Land and Beasts of Prey, this game easily beats both. When you enter this game you can instantly see a lot of work was put into it, with the huge highly detailed island, with the dinosaur models with textures done so well and the very nice ground vegetation which give the game such a great sense of realism.

As a hunting game, the AI needs a lot of work, they are not buggy but rather dumb, like zombies in DayZ, and if they spot you they are close to impossible to kill, which in some cases can become frustrating. The mobile tracker device works perfectly, but I feel as if the original game deserves that credit.

As a survival game I get a nice immersed horrified feeling, the aspects of this game can really come off quite scary, as the forest tried so hard to do.

So far I can say that it is worth the money, the game shows hard work by the developers, and I have hope they can maintain creating a more realistic primal hunting game.

reviewText:
(sigh...) Lets be clear about this: I loved this game, I still do. But I cannot recommend this to anyone at all just because it is extremely unfinished. When the Pre-alpha started in December I had really high hopes for this game. But I quickly realized that a really buggy pre-alpha really hurt the publicity of this game, so much that I feared that this game would be scrapped. It seems as if my fears have come true.

As a $30 dollar game it is alright. The objective of the game is to survive long enough so that you can gear up and hunt dinosaurs. It follows the basic structure of thehunter in that the OBJECTIVE is hunting. This confused allot of people at the beginning, they thought it was a DayZ with dino's which it is not. With a large Island and a 5 species of dinosaurs you can have alot of fun. Running from Raptors, hunting Triceratops, and teaming up to kill T-Rexes is essentially what you will be doing. Most of this game revolves around teamwork to take down the biggest and baddest of dinosaurs. This is really what made this game stand out. It fostered a teambuilding enviroment without holding your hand. But as with most pre-alpha's it had its downsides.

It started with only 3 types of dinosaurs (which grew to 5 types) which really wasn't that great. The weapons were lacking, the AI was terrible and it was all around a buggy game. Over the past 3 months the developers had been working really hard to polish up the pre-alpha and so it seemed as if everything was going just fine. Alas that was not the case...

Currently the game still feels like its stuck in pre-alpha, there are still bugs, a low amount of content, AI STILL SUCKS, there are only a few weapons in game, and in general it is unfinished all around. This really sucks as it had alot of potential to ge a GREAT game but in its current iteration I WOULD GIVE IT A 5/10 AT BEST.

Will I still play it, Yeah. But I would not advise you to buy it. Hopefully the devs will continue to produce more content and this jewel of a game can be saved. If they do fix it I will revisit this revew but for now, save your money and buy any of the other great indie games out there. It will be a much better use of your time and money.

reviewText:
So I’ve noticed that this game has mixed reviews, most of the negative ones being written by people who have played it for a couple of hours and have been eaten alive, chewed up and spat back out only to be able to write  “this game sucks”. Well my fellow steamers, you are in luck! You’re about to get a summary from someone who’s played the game for 87 hours.

I did write a ton about thehunter: Primal, but figured who will want to read a review the same size as The Wall the Nights Watch guard? So I’ve kindly summarised it.

•	thehunter: Primal is an online hunting survival game.

•	There are 5 different types of dinosaur,

•	11 different weapons and many items.

•	There is a shop where you can use in-game currency to buy weapons and items however you need to unlock them by levelling up. (It is not a P2W game)

•	Everything wants to kill you.

•	Hunting is similar to thehunter, you need to shoot the dinosaurs in the right place. But as the dinosaurs are usually trying to find you, you come across them more often.

•	It is hard and challenging, but you get used to it once you've played for a few hours.

•	There are no 24/7 servers and setting up your own can be difficult as you have to open ports.

•	You can be a lone wolf or chose to band together with friends or you can try to make friends. However if playing the PVP mode, only team up with people you trust, as it’s a dog eat dog world out there.



Pros
•	It’s hard to play, but rewarding when you do well.

•	Great game to play with friends.

•	Very big map.

•	PVP is fun.

•	Levelling up system.

•	In-game shop.

•	Updated by devs.

•	At moments you are terrified.

•	Nice to hunt and be hunted.

•	Day and Night.

•	You get immersed in the world.

•	Great dinosaur behaviour.



Cons

•	It’s hard to play, and annoying when you die a lot.

•	PVP can be brutal.

•	No 24/7 Severs and setting up your own can be a pain as you have to open ports.

•	Render distance is similar to thehunter so dinosaurs/humans disappear when they get too far (however they have to be quite far to disappear.)

•	Hit points on humans need to improve.

•	Levelling up system needs something to show hunters how close they are to the next level.

•	Transition from night to day needs to improve.



If you like to be challenged then this is a good game for you, especially the PVP. Hunting dinosaurs is really exciting and something cool is always happening in the game. This is the kind of thing you will expect:

You’ve been tracking a Triceratops you shot for the last 10 minutes, and you’re lead into a forest. Suddenly you hear raptors communicating with each other, then silence and a rush of footsteps. Screams from the U-Raptors fill your ears and you and your hunting party start manically firing at 5 U-Raptors ambushing you.

Whilst PVPing you're making your way up the volcano with your hunting party and are hounded by the flying Quetzalcoatlus,  one of your party is caught by the Quetzalcoatlus and he’s flown into the sky and then dropped to his death. But the rest of you manage to make it to the base at the top. However a rival hunting party is already there and a fire fight ensues. Your team get mascaraed and you lose all your stuff.

Or you’re walking through the open plains and start hearing thud after thud and the ground begins to shake, you realise a T-Rex is coming for you and all you can do is run. But remember you have a high calibre weapon so try to take it on. You begin shooting at it and its getting closer and closer, just as it’s about to rip you to pieces you see an opening to its heart and shoot your .700, killing it instantly.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, Primal.

What can I say about Primal.

Well in what other games are you forced to hide in a bush for half an hour with you buddy, whilst cowering from a T Rex?

Honestly though, quite a good game, ill go over some pros and cons.

Good:

The atmospheric nature of the game is great; both the sounds and graphics are quite pretty.
The core game play is actually pretty nailed down despite it being early access, you can shoot Dinosaurs and throw rocks and what ever, what more do you need?
Despite there being little in game right now, it's actually quite fun grouping up with your buddies and treking through the jungle, surviving and all that jazz.

Bad:

The game lacks some content, I mean, we could do with some more guns, maybe some dynamic events. Base building would be great in this game. Then again, early access so what ever, no big deal.
Run speed at the current gesture comes in two catagories: Faster than light or extremely slow. It would be nice to get a happy medium.
The lobby/hosting needs some work.
The Dinosaurs can be quite stupid sometimes, then again, they had small brains right?


All in all, I reccomend this game, especially if you want to waste £15 and possibily have some fun doing it. I mean, its not the greatest game in the world, you'll find out how much patience you have and you will be in a bush for 80% of your game time, but even that being said, it's oddly addictive and way more fun with others.

reviewText:
Updated April 1st Release:
This is NOT a full release of a game.  It should be labeled as being in BETA at best.  Models and environment are top-notch.  Dino attacks still need some serious work.  Simple things like a drag-and-drop inventory aren't finished yet.  And most of all there's still no realistic interaction between the dinos, i.e. dinos preying on other dinos.  But its a lot better than it was.  It's getting there.  It has SO MUCH potential.

This may be one of my all-time favorite games. But its not for everyone. It's like being a cop, I suspect. A midget cop in a barbarian cannibal universe. Armed with a big ♥♥♥♥ing gun. That you don't always have ammo for. So you hide in a trash can and watch them eat your friends and neighbors and wait for them to leave. So you can get the ammo left on their fly-blown corpses. So you can track those barbarian cannibals down and explode their livers. Then you take selfies with their dead bodies.


Early Release Review:
I will say up front that this is a hunting game.  You can spend a lot of time where nothing happens.  Ammo can be feast or famine, as it should be in a survival game.  The game pays off for those with patience and persistence.  You can sprint around so long as you hear nothing.  When you hear raptors, you have to slow down.  Move away.  Make like a hole in the water."

Despite its myriad of disastrous alpha bugs and severe lack of content
date: I LOVE this game.  The environment is best I've ever seen.  There's a real feeling of terror when you hear a pack of raptors and have 2 shells left.  Or you're solo armed modestly with a Tyrannosaur  20m that has your scent.  Surviving encounters like this and the eventual vengeance exacted through patience and planning is exhilarating.  Teaming up and taking down a T-rex is fantastic fun.\n\nBeginning tips:  Weapons are at the settlements.  Download a basic map that shows the settlement locs and you'll have a gun in no time.  Ammo is found randomly in the wild.  Then find someone you can tag along with and work with them to get camo and ammo.  Once you've done this
recommended: the game really opens up for you.  Shoot for the heart/lungs/spine.  With the bow
hoursPlayed: don't wait for them to get right up on you.  Work for a clean LOS to the target and reveal yourself at > 10 meters so they come straight at you
voteText: exposing their chest for a killshot."

reviewText:
I really like The Hunter: Primal, but I am disappointed about it's lack of content. I am hoping the developers would eventually develop as much variety as The Hunter has, many maps, many guns, many dinosaur types. It's rather limited at the moment on what it has to offer and as of now they have stated they aren't working on any major content releases.

I am enjoying it, none the less. But I have a hard time 100% recommending anyone purchase it, considering it could quickly become a bit tedious and boring to some who have no interest in the PvP mode.

I'm going to include the table I made for comparison with a similar game. Ultimately I recommend Primal for those looking for a more demanding experience, but only if you're the more patient type. There's a lot of walking around in between the action.

If you've got a twitchy trigger finger and you just want to hunt a lot of dinosaurs without a lot of walking, Carnivores: Dinosaur Hunter Reborn might be more your speed and a little easier on your wallet.

Category        TH: Primal        Carnivores: DHR                Weapons:        More Realistic, Better Feel, More Variety (11 types), Limited Upgrades (May be able to attach a scope on some weapons)        More Arcadey, Less Variety (4 types), More Upgrades (3-4 per weapon, though not visual)                Scenery:        Very realistic, detailed, one very large map, very pretty        More cartoony, detailed, several moderately sized maps, nice to look at                Dinosaurs:        Very limited variety (5 species), mostly carnivores        Larger variety, (9 species) carnivores and herbivores                Difficulty:        Challenging        Casual                Modes:        Singleplayer and Multiplayer (PvE & PvP)        Singleplayer Only                Price:        $29.99        $14.99

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all this is by far one of if not the best survival game i played. And I have a lot of experience in survival gaming.

You cannot compare it any of other genre-like titles (e.g. Dayz, Forest,..)
It is focused on hunting, while you are equally hunted by carnivores and players.

+ real-looking island/jungle
+ intense and terrifying atmosphere
+ good teamplay/PVP
+ real-looking models
+ outstanding sound design (!)
+ exploring
+ looting
+ smart AI
+ no need to eat/drink
+ no crafting
+ realistic hitzones - it is a hunting sim!
+ very challenging - it is not meant to be easy!

- some bugs
- no dedicated servers yet
- too less animal wildlife
- too less gear at the moment
- Island could be a bigger imo
- needs more playermodels (customization)
- maybe to harsh for new unexperienced hunters

All in all, it is early access, but it is already a great success for me. Finally I found the hunting game I was always dreaming of. You remember Carnivores? Go get The Hunter Primal, this one's for you!

reviewText:
I love the feel of this game!  This is a game of intense experiences.  It has stired a gaming interest in me that I haven't had in years.

For instance, you are fighting one T-Rex when you hear the sounds of a second T-Rex joining the fight.  You don't have enough ammo to take on a second T-Rex and you are in the open.  You are down to your last couple of shells as the first T-Rex drops but the second is closing in fast, so you go prone and start to back away into some heavy brush and slowly you do actually escape even though the second T-Rex is right in front of you and you manage to survive the encounter.

Or you leave your drop pod to retrieve your items and you buy a lot of ammo but no rifle because your corpse has one already.  On the way to get your items on your corpse, you hear the raptors closing in and there is no way you can survive their attack with your machete.  If you die you will have your main loot on one corpse and a ton of ammo on another in a different location.  You don't want to die so you try to evade the raptors but they catch up and start to attack.  You try to dodge their lunges and then you hear the foot steps of a T-Rex in the nearby woods so you dash to the woods with the raptors in pursuit.  As the T-Rex appoaches to see what the fuss is about the raptors retreat and you back slowly away from the T-Rex on your belly.  After some time of keeping a large tree between you and the T-Rex you get up and make the rest of the journey to retrieve your items.

There are literally dozens of times I've had situations where I felt a sense of accomplishment because of the way a situation played out.  I just find the experiences to be rewarding when I find a way to survive a situation where the odds were not in my favor.  However, the game will challenge you and you will die quite often especially when you are starting out.  It is part of the game.

That said the game isn't perfect but I didn't expect perfection for $20 (the Early Access price I paid).  There are still bugs that have been around for some time but they have been issuing patches weekly to address them.

The official release was a sad moment for me though simply because the game could have used another month or two of polish.  I'm not one that is complaining about content because the content in the game at release is what the dev's said they would release but more content would obviously be welcome.

Unfortunately, the release update was essentially game breaking.  I have no idea why the game was released the way it was.  The game literally oozes potential so to see it take such an unnecessary hit was truly unfortunate.  There are a ton of negative reviews as a result but the game breaking bugs that were introduced in the release update were addressed within two days.   The game is enjoyable again and the dev's are looking to address some gameplay issues with the Quetzaloatlus in the next patch.

This game feels like a survival game to me because you are truly trying to survive long enough to find that next batch of ammo or the next weapon but it is not a crafting game.  So if you feel that you have to have crafting and structures in order to be a survival game then this game isn't for you.

This game is unique and I hope it generates enough sales to make further development worthwhile.  Even if the game development stopped at this point it is money well spent if you enjoy the idea of hunting dinosaurs while being hunted yourself.  There are very intense moments and those are the moments that keep me coming back.

To be clear, this game is not a run and gun game.  If you want to feel like Rambo and run out killing everything in your path you are not going to have a good experience.  This is a much slower paced game that requires some patience.

Whether or not you will enjoy a game such as this really depends on your personality.  If you like fast paced action at all times then this game probably isn't for you.  If you enjoy stealth and a slower pace with frantic moments then this game will most likely appeal to you.

The dev's appear to still be on a weekly update cycle even after release so bug fixes and gameplay tweaks are ongoing.  The game is not perfect but if you wait for perfection you will most likely be waiting a long time and you will be missing out on a lot of fun in the mean time.

One of the more humorous bugs is some of the dino's clip through solid objects.  Things like a T-Rex literally clipping his head through concrete.  Some people freak out about this and it can be irritating when you get killed in such a way but once you know it is possible you simply avoid putting yourself into that situation again.

For instance, I was using one of the new concrete tower structures that was recently added and had two T-Rex's on me.  As I entered the structure and ran upstairs I run into two T-Rex heads inside the structure.  They both stuck their heads straight through the wall on the second floor of the structure.  I literally screamed out loud when I nearly ran into their mouths.  It was a funny moment!  I just ran back downstairs got them to move a bit and then proceeded to the top to kill them both.  The dev's are still working on the clipping issues.

The way I approach whether a game like this is worth it is based on how much I've played the game comparied to the cost.  It is pretty obvious that I've got my money's worth considering I've played over 250 hours at this point and still play daily.  So I highly recommend the game, warts and all, simply because there is enough value to make it worth the expense in my opinion.  Only you can decide if you would get the same value out of it.

reviewText:
I love the feel of this game!  This is a game of intense experiences.  It has stired a gaming interest in me that I haven't had in years.

For instance, you are fighting one T-Rex when you hear the sounds of a second T-Rex joining the fight.  You don't have enough ammo to take on a second T-Rex and you are in the open.  You are down to your last couple of shells as the first T-Rex drops but the second is closing in fast, so you go prone and start to back away into some heavy brush and slowly you do actually escape even though the second T-Rex is right in front of you and you manage to survive the encounter.

Or you leave your drop pod to retrieve your items and you buy a lot of ammo but no rifle because your corpse has one already.  On the way to get your items on your corpse, you hear the raptors closing in and there is no way you can survive their attack with your machete.  If you die you will have your main loot on one corpse and a ton of ammo on another in a different location.  You don't want to die so you try to evade the raptors but they catch up and start to attack.  You try to dodge their lunges and then you hear the foot steps of a T-Rex in the nearby woods so you dash to the woods with the raptors in pursuit. reviewText:
I've been putting off reviewing theHunter: Primal for a long time now, but considering the amount of time I've sunk into it, I'm going to give it my best shot. I've always debated as to whether or not I could recommend this game to someone, and it's honestly a hard choice. If there was an option between recommending and not recommending, I would go with that one. There are many great things about this game, but also many frustrating things, so I feel like a pros and cons list would best suit my review.

PROS:
The map - The map itself is simply one large island with many points of interest, ranging from bases with torn down concrete structures and in-tact bunkers on the ground or on the side of a volcano (not active), to small campsites. When you first start off, it's fun to make it your goal to visit all of the bases on your map, since they provide the gear you need to survive. The rest of the map is fairly diverse, from dense forests, to large open plains. I had a blast exploring the map for the first time, and I would think other people will too if you don't mind a lot of walking.

The graphics - To add to the fact that you'll be doing a lot of walking, you can still appreciate the graphics the game has to offer. Granted, they aren't amazing like certain triple-A titles today, but they are still impressive and can make for some beautiful scenes on the island.

Weapons/gear - I've always liked the choice of weapons in the game. If you fancy shotguns, rifles, handguns, or even a sniper rifle, you can find them all here. You can even unlock an assault rifle once you reach end-game content. The gear system is nice as well, as it has an impact on your visibility to dinosaurs. You start off in bright orange clothing but can work your way to camo that makes you very hard to detect, thus finding new gear can be rewarding.NEUTRAL:
The dinosaurs - It's unfortunate that the dinosaurs themselves are fairly lackluster. The game is filled with nothing but carnivores/dinosaurs that will attack on sight. There are only 5 species of dinosaurs, and one of which (the Quetzalcoatlus) is quite irritating to deal with, despite being reworked several times. The AI is good for the most part, but once you shoot anything it will head towards you like a heat-seeking missle, because apparently they can see you from anywhere. However, I will hand it to the game for having an organ system for all species, meaning every shot counts. You won't be taking down a T-rex easily by randomly shooting it in the body. However, if you know where the heart is and can hit it only a few times, they can go down quick. Same with all others in the game. You can even one-shot triceratops and raptors if you become familiar with the dinosaurs' anatomy. One other thing I should also note is that there are also variations of the dinosaurs, so you never know when you might come across an uncommon or rare dinosaur, which does add to the gameplay nicely.

End-game" content - Once you've done basically everything

reviewText:
TheHunter: PRIMAL

OVERVIEW

OK.... So theHunter: Primal is very very similar to theHunter (obviously) however the main difference are the fact that you cannot purchase anything and then equip them when you first start because it is not a hunting expedition, it's survival... However they have just added an in-game money system, where everytime you harvest a dino, you get money and when you level up, you unlock something in the shop, so when you die, you get taken to a shop where you can purchase weapons and whatnot before you spawn...

But it's not like other survival games... you can't build stuff... you basically just gotta scavenge containers and bags and/or kill other players and take their stuff... if it's set to PVP of course...

The graphics are a little better than the hunter in my opinion and who can ever forget the beautiful sunrise and sunset water colours... and choice scenery!

As far as gameplay, the mechanics are buggy, but can only get better with time. The player movements are different from the Hunter the walking and running are faster, but they have introduced a sprint system which uses stamina and is extremely loud to attract dinosaurs. (Only use in emergency) The hunter mate (although called settler mate) works exactly the same way, spotting and tracking works the same but there isn’t tracking or spotting skill levels, and of course trophy shots and harvesting work the same way also. You don't get experience for weapon use in this game either...

There is also a new tracking feature in which I really like... when you wound an animal and you track it's blood, it tells you in percentage how injured it is... for eg.... after shooting a T-Rex 6 times with a shotgun, after scanning it's blood it told me that it had 45-60% health left and the next time I shot it once... it said 30-48% (as well as body/intestine shot etc)

THE GOOD

- Great graphics
- Excellent immersion (especially when the t-rex is nearby or when a raptor knows you're there and he/she calls out to the pack to help look for you)
- Cool map with central volcano (no dinosaur game is complete without a volcano to set the mood)
- Has major potential for many wonderful things
- No pay to win, no money at all (except in-game currency from harvesting)
- Injury percentage for prey
- When you die, you can retrieve your goods from your old backpack... as long as no-one else has pillaged it!!
- Thunderstorms :D
- Mean looking dinosaurs

THE BAD

- Lots of gameplay bugs and a rushed full release from Early Access
- Only five dinosaurs... T-Rex, Utahraptors, Triceratops, Velociraptors and Quetzalcoatlus (Dino-birds)
- Scavenging gets boring and old really quickly - needs traditional ‘the Hunter’ mode
- Controls are very stiff and sometimes sluggish
- Bad framerates in high detailed areas such as swamps and dense jungle regions
- Faulty hit register, (shoot the 6,000kg T-Rex in the heart with a .700 while it's standing still and it registers as only a body hit, where sometimes I can drop a 10,000kg Triceratops on the run with one .308 round to the heart, where the bullet hole is on the leg... Can be quite frustrating at times... as you die from not dropping them or you run out of ammo...
- Quetzalcoatlus seem to be able to swoop through hilly terrain and through metal spikes and grab you, even though you shot them in the head...
- Sound is a little buggy crossing from biome to biome
- The Quetzalcoatlus, although remarkable are very annoying and frustrating to deal with at times...

WHAT IT NEEDS

- Need to be able to craft something, to build defences to stand a chance killing dinosaurs without dying
- Needs more dinosaur species (especially herbivores) and less of the current ones for a nice balanced game
- Need to see the Dinosaurs attacking each other... raptors attacking T-rex and Triceratops, Velociraptors getting taken by Quetzalcoatlus and the traditional T-Rex versus triceratops battle...
- Maybe a 4 wheeler would be good as usually the game spawns you on the other side of the map as your friends
- The T-rex needs to have a bigger roar like on Jurassic Park... to really make your hairs stand on end.
- A traditional ‘the Hunter’ mode, to create expeditions instead of scrounging around...

VERDICT

Overall I give this game a 6.5/10, well worth $15 - $20 AUD MAX... but knowing the developers... they did such an awesome job with ‘the Hunter’... So I expect the same with this... So if you like the Hunter I recommend getting ‘the Hunter: Primal’, especially since Dinosaurs will soon be ruling Hollywood again, it's nice to finally see a switch from zombie survival for once.

Also a funny thing... when you find some T-Rex poo, you'll notice it has human arms and some skulls in it... fkn hilarious!! Even funnier than that Jurassic Park satellite phone scene!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I guess I'll write a few things about the game. TL:DR version at bottom, even that is long.

First things first, this is an EA release which means its full of issues and is incomplete as far as content goes. Visually it looks very good, and the sounds are good though there are a few glitches, especially when standing near someone who is trigger happy, or about to be eaten.  The issues I have no doubt will be ironed out but their release target of early March 2015 is rapidly approaching.  And as far as content, if this game ends up getting the same kind of attention to updates and additions as theHunter has, then we will not be wanting for different critters to hunt, or varying types of gear.

As far as the gameplay goes this is one of the most fun games I've played in quite a while, and doubly so when playing with friends. And you do need to play with some friends or at least make some and travel around in a group, as your suvival chances are very slim with no allies.  The only thing that becomes an issue when in a large group is ammunition, as there is usually a shortage for everyone, not like that is better for solo players however.
The problem here lies in the loot tables, or rather the amount of loot/ammo whatever that shows up in each box. The boxes need to have at least double the ammo available if not more, and there really is no point in having a stack of 1 round that you cannot merge into other stacks, same with healing sprays.(Fixed! You can now stack ammo and stuff, GJ Devs!)

Players shold be able to jump, and possibly climb low walls and rocks.

And lastly, as with theHunter, there really needs to be dedicated servers for this game, as the host/client connection issues that plague theHunter are present in this game, with players timing out or crashing every few minutes, it can become frustrating just to play for a few hours.

TL;DR version

Pros-
Amazingly fun with a group.
Good visuals, some of the scenery is quite beautiful.
Good sound, the sound of a T-Rex stomping near me makes my whole house shake with the sound turned up!
Great potential

Cons-
Incredibly high learning curve.
Exceptionally difficult almost futile to play solo, turning some gamers away, and others to hacking/exploits.
Obvious glitches and bugs that would cripple a live release (I expect they will fix this by release)
No Dedicated Servers, and with the crappy hosting/client system this will keep many players from fully experiencing the game.
Tiny pool of creatures to hunt (Obvious that more will be added)
Small pool of weapons (also expect this to change soon; WTF no .50 BMG? SRS GIEZ)
No combining stacks of ammo or healing sprays? (Fixed stacking now works!)
Very low loot tables, crates need at least double the ammo/healing loot if not more.
No jumping, climbing or swimming, cause these trained dinosaur hunters haven't learned that, and they can't even run very far.
Any idiot can hack the game, at the very least, hosts need to be able to ban players from their servers, as one bad experience can ruin the game for people.

Takeaway: Great fun with a few friends and easily worth 20 bucks.

reviewText:
If you don't like the hunter you probably wont like this game. That's just the way it is! Its not for the cod or bf2 fans. Its not run and gunning and running around without consequences. You have to play it like you are actually hunting or as close to that as you can get in a game. If you run you'll only spook the herbivores and call the predators. You have to place your shots. I see all these videos and almost 90% of the time they shoot for the head. You must go for those body shots, Like real hunting specifically the vitals besides dinos in this game have small brains and the chance of hitting them there is slim if at all. Hit em in the hart or the lungs and their gona go down if not immediately then within a few feet. Your the hunter and the hunted depending on the situation.
Ive only been playing about 7 hours but I haven't died once yet, have no room left to carry anything and I have full camo because im careful and not in any rush. Ive never used the run meter once because you don't even need it if you play the way the game is intended. The metter is also for swinging handheld weapons so conserve it if you like to use it for running. The game is also very beautiful especially when everything is on high.
With all this said, are there issues with the game? Of course. Is the game getting better? I think so and the immersion is really that good especially the thunder and lightening. Dinos do get stuck on cliffs, the t-rex has some issues and yes there is no swimming to name a few. Basically  I think that most of the complaints are from people who expect this game to be something it never was going to be. I also believe the games not the problem here its the people who play it, then complain that its not what THEY expected it to be.
Like I said at the beginning of this review, If you like the hunter than you'll like the the hunter primal. If your looking for run and gun or a swimming simulator then go play something else because this isn't it nor will it ever be. Please also remember, when they say realistic that is also realative! My deffinition of what realistic is, of course is different than yours but as games go this one comes very close. If its not realistic enough for you then I suggest going outside and doing some real hunting!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been avoiding early access recently, too many games on there that feel like a 2nd year computer games students university project floated on steam to make some undergraduate a little extra beer money, too often left buggy and unfinished, all that promise, and my cash, gone.

Fortunately then, for theHunter: Primal that isnt the case here, and the game is in development by a studio that I've known and come to trust for a number of years now, who are commited to working with their community, and have a good solid history of regular updates and not abandoning their projects.

Since I picked up the game on release yesterday, I've already seen 3 updates to the game pushed out, just off the back of tweaks the team realised were necessary from the early initial reports, which to me is suggestive of a good team.

Built with the same avalanche engine that powers the games older brother"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL:DR > The game is great, if you liked The Hunter, this is an even better experience, and not haunted by monthly pay to plays subscription. If you're above the fence about buying it, just do it, you won't regret.

Now to the review:

First things first, i liked a lot The Hunter but i just could not stand the huge monthly pricing, it would probably be one of my favourite games if you could just pay it once and play forever. So, when i saw this game, i did not had much option other than to just buy, a game so similar to the hunter being pay it only once with no micro transations? I'm in!

About the game> This is The Hunter on steroids, you are stranded on a wild planet, you've been sent as cannon fodder before the colonization, even though the lore is as basic as the Avatar movie, it is enough to get you going. You start off with just a bow and a few arrows, and you have to scavenge drop boxes left around the planet if you want to survive, and, while you do that, you get to hunt dinossaurs.

Hunting dinossaurs is a bit different from hunting wild boars, the carnivores won't hesitate to have you as their next meal, and they don't lack the ability to track you down. Most of the times, it is best to just let your prey go than to engage in combat, if you lack the element of surprise, this is not The Hunter, this is Be Hunted. You will find yourself lots of times listening closely for clues about your foes as you crawl away through the dense foliage, not for the faint hearted.

Exploring is just awesome as the world feals really life-like, with a awesome science-fiction touch as you see yourself orbiting another huge planet exploring a planet that highly resembles Earth. Bonus points for hunting with your friends, you won't forget the first triceratops you'll put down after a lot of teamwork, yes, the bow may not be the best weapon for hunting such beasts, but it surely can get the job done. Also, this comes to another point: can you play it offline? Yes, you can, but unlike The Hunter you WILL need some help taking down the larger animals and surviving the dinoes that hunt in pack, find some friends and do it together!

Also, as this game is based off on The Hunter, a hunting simulator, you can expect long walks and some frustrating situations,, but that is part of the features, if you don't like it, this game might not be for you.

Of course not everything is great, and, for now, probably we can blame early access for it, sometimes the interface gets clunky, or there might be some technical errors. I am not mentioning the lack of content, as there is way too few dinossaurs and guns to keep you interest for a long time, but it will probably get only better with time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(simple Pros and cons below)
So far, its good
Imagine being on the island from Jurassic Park 3 (ignore the movie, just the island itself)
You start with nothing but a bow and a couple arrows, you must find new weapons in buildings and boxes
There isnt a huge diversity of dinosaurs, but the ones in the game are good
It plays similar to thehunter, but you dont pick your loadout, there are no microtransactions, and you have a proper sprint function. Though shooting and everything else is basically the same as thehunter.
It is slow paced, you sneak around the jungle, avoiding the T-rex and maybe killing the smaller dinosaurs.
It seems like a game that would be good with a couple friends, all sneaking around trying to find better weapons.
overall it is a good dinosaur survival game, (though there is no food/water requirements, just health) thats slow paced, only has a few dinosaurs, decent atmosphere and good either singleplayer or multiplayer (it has pvp and pve)
id say for now in early access its a 7/10, though with more content and updates that will probably go up.
EDIT
After a bit more time, im going to talk about the atmosphere a bit more and do a basic pros and cons list.
In the regular game, you are wary of not disturbing the animals, but feel safe, though annoyed if you see a deer running away.
In Primal, you sneak around, constantly wary of not disturbing anything, like the first game, though you dont feel safe. If you are seen or heard, you might have a chance against the Utahraptors, but anything else will kill you or be very hard to kill. It adds a much more frightening atmosphere than the original, and is helped by the Jurassic Park-style destroyed facilities.

Pros-
+ Good Atmosphere
+ Nice Map (though there is only 1 at the moment)
+ shooting physics/mechanic, however it isnt the greatest at doing quick draws if you are attacked, so it much favors stealth
+ Decent Price
+ Good for single or multiplayer

Cons-
- Lack of dinosaur diversity
- only 1 map ( so yeh, pro and con for that)
- gameplay needs to be tweaked a bit so its easier to quickly shoot

Meh-
Cant change loot spawn rates or starting equipment. Though if you could it might ruin immersion and remove the challange

reviewText:
This game is great ... excellent graphics textures and terrain etc ...  devs did a good job on dinosaur AI, tracking and bullet damage system, which are hard things to get right.
It can be a hard and cruel game which makes it feel that much more rewarding when you get kills and find good weapons and ammo. It gets a bit easier when you get to level 20 and can buy shotgun and buckshot ammo to fight your way back to your backpack

If you want to realistically simulate hunting dinosaurs and like a challenge, this game does the job

If this is what you are looking for then you should ignore all the butthurt players posting reviews  who can't handle how hard the game is ... or expect some shiny new dinosaur, gun or hat to be added every week otherwise they rage quit.

It would be good if the devs were more focused on improving and expanding TheHunter:Primal but it doesn't stop what has been made so far from being a unique and enjoyable game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My current review:

Alright lets start with some things I see commonly come up:

-There is no Micro-transactions, it is a one time purchase.
-People seem to worry about it being abandoned like The Stomping Land. Avalanche Studios would have too much to lose if they ditched the game so do not see that happening. They are the ones responsible for the Just Cause games, I do not see them being willing to ditch a game to ruin sales of their other major games.
-Yes there is bugs, it is early access.
-Yes there is a lot of walking and patience required at some parts, this is hunting not a run and gun war game.

So far I am quite enjoying this game even at it's beginning state, from the amazing visuals to hunting and being hunted by dinosaurs.
There is currently 3 types of dinosaurs, 2 more planned during Early Access phase before release. You start off next to a pod in which you will receive a bow, arrows, and a map fragment, these items are quite weak (but can kill if used properly) and after exploring and surviving the dinosaur inhabitants you will stumble upon encampments and chests in which you can find loot. This can be anything from ammo, camo, health right up to guns.

If you are not careful you could wind up in the jaws of a T-Rex or ambushed by a pack of Raptors. Stealth is your friend when hunting these creatures. T-Rexs are not really advisable to hunt alone as they are extremely tough to take down but with a group of fellow hunters you can take them on. Raptors can track you and even plan to flank you, plenty of times some will creep up on you without you even noticing keeping you on your toes a lot of the time.

Your items go with you after you relog or switch servers, they are with you until you die at which point if you want your items back you will have to run back to where you died to reclaim your items if someone has not already looted your items. PVP is an option for servers to have as well.

Some people do complain about the damage of the weapons against the dinosaurs but the thing is, they're dinosaurs, not thin skinned humans. They have thick skin, thick skulls and small brains, you want to aim for vital organs such as the lungs/heart for the maximum effectiveness. A well placed shot will take down a Raptor in one shot, a T-Rex can be taken down with several well placed shots although if you hit in a not so vulnerable area it will take a lot more to take the mighty beasts down. Animals if hurt enough will bleed out over time as well, so do not just automatically expect a fleeing animal survived. Even the mighty T-Rex may flee if hurt enough.

I do not want to give much about the story of the game away, but there is a bit of a storyline behind it which you will discover while playing if you keep your eyes peeled out for such things.

As for bugs, there is a few and I have crashed a few times but not enough for me to really complain.

I could go on but this is already long. Overall if this is your type of game and do not mind supporting Early Access titles I would recommend it, if that does not sound like your thing, then wait it out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Summary: I really normally don't plug early access games because I've been irritated by them in the past, but as of this moment this game is a whole lot of fun. It's one of those 'survival sandbox' types, except.. streamlined? You have health, stamina, your only way of regaining health is rare-ish healing items and rare as crap mushrooms. You start with a bow and 10 arrows, bright friggin orange jumpsuit, and your trusty PDA map thingy. You pick your way through the landscape trying not to die and also find weapons/clothing/equipment at various ruined resource caches throughout the map. It's made with the engine of the prolific hunting game by the name of: TheHunter that i've played years off steam.

TL:DR
Pros:
Realistic AI: 'The hunter has become the hunted, hurrdurr'
Satisfying gun/bowplay: Bloodsplats, you see your impacts and arrows sticking out of stuff.
Varied-ish, huge map: You are on a giant subtropical island, swamps, beaches, mountains, and volcanic terrain
Potential: TheHunter devs have been updating that game for years, and as satisfying as this is right now, wow!

Cons:
Servers: You basically have to make a solo multiplayer game to play, even if by yourself. As of this moment the only multiplayer games joinable are from folks who bothered to forward ports and all that. I hope that changes down the road as someone that enjoys multiplayer but also has a somewhat unstable connection.
Steep difficulty curve: While by no means impossible, it so far has taken a long time to walk away from an encounter with raptors alive 50% of the time, not to mention with only a bow. I consider this game to be a DayZ lite, in that regard.
Limited content: Despite my adoration of the game, as of this moment there isn't an awful lot in terms of weaponry/dinos to hunt/be hunted. 4 guns, I think 4 different outfits (counting hats and glasses and so on) 1 bow, 3 healing items, misc hunting gear, T-rex, Utahraptors, Triceratops.


All in all I totally reccomend this game for folks looking for a realistic sort of shooter where you roam around and loot stuff to survive and prosper. It's a survival game without the eating/drinking, which IMO leaves you a lot more time to worry about the staring at the t-rex 10 meters away while shivering.

Get this is you like ultra realistic walking simulators

Get this to realise just how quickly you'd be eaten by dinos in real life
And FINALLY, get this game if you like to be chased and eaten by Utahraptors in 5 seconds...

Awesome Game.

reviewText:
I wish it had more then 5 dinos...but its never going to get more.
Pros: World is massive.
- Sounds are fantastic, and scary. Gunfire sounds extremely well in this game. You can hear a fellow hunter over 800m away fire round after round as he is swarmed by raptors.  Raptors sound great and you can hear them close in on you.
-Terrain does what it should, the forest and different areas are very dense with foilage. So raptors can get real close to you without you seeing them. Stealth is a MAJOR part of gameplay.
-The community seems very friendly and willing to help you or talk with you. Almost every game ive joined ive left adding a friend on steam.  Hunting together is extremely fun and has saved my life a few times being in a larger group. In that same note, ive seen 2 t-rexs tear up a crowd of players in a valley i was attempting to join up with.
-The actual hunting can be really fun, as these dinosaurs can be tracked across the entire map, provided your skilled enough to keep their trail. It looks similiar to what i believe evolve is going to have for tracks. You can use dino calls, you scavenge for your gear like a dayz game, but your customizing and inventory is like an old school resident evil. Not much to it yet, there are scopes and different weapons but not many so far. 1 bow, 1 pistol, 2 rifles, 1 shotgun. different rounds for them liek the shotty has buck and slug.
The cons:
-DINO AI..(sometimes)......it needs patching but potential is there. A dinosaur can hear you, see you, and even track you. The raptors work in packs and can provide an issue because you do seem to get attacked by them from multpile directions. However, sometimes they charge past you, or walk right by you even tho your not hidden, they walk funny up hills, they sometimes aimlessly make wierd turns,The trex seems to have a few malfunctions aswell. Theres only 3 dinosaurs at the moment, with what i assume is ALOT more to come. SOmetimes dinosaurs stand there or get stuck and you can take them down easily. Other times, you get killed and never even saw it coming. Due to the small amount of species in the game thus far, their interactions from what i have seen are minimal. Smaller dinos run away from the big one. I would love to see the world become more alive in future updates. Maybe come over a hill and find a pack of raptors attacking a herd of herbavores or a single trex. I wish the raptors necks would turn to acknowldge you, the seem very rigid at times. other times its fine.

Conclusion
Its in alpha, and its already as solid as the carnivors games we had on pc in the early 2000s. Even with the bugs, that we all know alphas must go through, this game is a blast, and i do recommend it alsong as you dont get mad easily and can undertsand there will be problems as the game polishes out. I am having a blast though.
..I made this 1min 40 sec youtube video of the game just for fun,

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lZH7idrkI58&feature=youtu.be
