reviewText:
Been playing since early access with over 160 hours of exploring the game solo and with groups of up to 6 people. Overall I like the game. I’m not going to go in to the balance and state of the game as of this review because that changes from patch. Instead I am going to cover how I play the game, and some of the notable aspects that struck me. Side note, I have never played any hunting games (The Hunter or otherwise) and do not have an interest in doing so. I have yet to try any of the PVP but having played the original DAYZ mod for Arma 2… ya I’ll just stick to the PvE where the humans can’t ruin your day.
First off, the visuals started out very decent and just got better over time. Now in April of 2015, the weather effects are absolutely fantastic and wandering around the island is still breathtaking. And it’s not just grand vistas, it’s the attention to detail. The little PDA you use that shows what you are looking at in game is accurate when another player looks at your PDA for example. You can see the world reflect in other players eyes, the leaves from trees blow in a uniform direction to denote wind. It’s little things like that which impressed me.
Another interesting feature of the game is the sound. This is one of the few games where it actually matters. Almost any game I have played, I really could blair music or have a movie playing at the same time and not be affected. In Primal, everything is silenced but the game sounds. Even after you get comfortable with the game, the sounds are essential to knowing what’s coming and what it is. I found that having a nice subwoofer is one of the best early warning T-Rex detection systems available :-).
My third point is the most subjective but you are reading my review so you’re going to get my opinions. In my opinion, the game is beyond my patience and skill to play solo and enjoy; it’s too hard. I found I had much more fun with a small group, even if it was just one other person (WITH VOICE CHAT). If I did not have friends to play with, I probably would have abandoned the game after a few hours of exploring and being eaten. Not only can you be overwhelmed by dinosaurs but the supplies in the game are relatively scarce. This is not a complaint; I LIKE that things are scarce and that you are often down to a few precious rounds and if those fail, you are likely to die. But because there is that element of chance and that “being in the wrong place at the wrong time” aspect, the few people working with you can avert a total loss into a narrow escape or only a few deaths. Even after you are pimped out in the noble came and have whatever weapons you wanted, you are just as frail as you were when you landed and having the most powerful gun does NOT mean you are safe.
So overall, I am pleased with the game. You need 2-3 hour sections of time to really enjoy it when you hop on so don’t think you are going to play for 20 minute and be fine when you log on next, but I am happy with the time I have got out of it to date.

reviewText:
After almost 20 hours I realize what this game is trying to do, it's a fine game, but not more than 5 dollars in fines.

You're Roland in jurassic park 2, a hunter that got so bored with deer he became bald and decided to hunt dinosaurs.

A dinosaur shooter can have you replace the dinosaurs with pokemons, or zombies, it won't feel much different, you shoot the small once, the big twice.

However this is a hunting game, with dinosaurs. Hunting games have its roots in realism, covering mechanics of smell, wind, weather, anatomy, bullet calibres, camouflage. These features all play a part in your success of hunting the prey. In other words, shooting everything in the face won't work out when your'e facing an animal with the skull thickness of armor plating on a T51 tank and the capability kill you before you finish reloading a magazine.

The game doesn't give many tools, because it wants to be a survival game, they expect people to come in, know how hunting games work, and apply that to survivalism and dinosaurs, when most people think this is killing floor with dinosaurs, myself included.

A big realization of the difference of this game is, how your prey will almost always outrun you when its health gets low. This occurs almost all the time, provided that everyone spawns with a knife at level 1, they run faster, hit harder, and have more bodies than you.

So what do you do to succeed, you run, you hide, you scavenge other players bodies, and abandoned outposts for weapons.

Because in this game, access to weapons doesn't mean it gets easier, it just allows you to make more mistakes. A player can use a bow and one shot a triceratops if you aim for its heart and because ammo is limited, it is encouraged to do so.

You hide in the woods, listen for the noise and stalk the pack, finding one triceratops by itself muching grass, by watching the foliage you figure out the wind direction, staying downwind, so it can't detect you by smell, you crouch up to its side of the belly, drawing the bow, aiming for the spot behind the joint of the foreleg, a direct hit pierces its heart and kills it instantly, while the kid that plays call of duty is shooting it with a 50 cal, 11 times on the crown of its skull doing 1% total damage.

If you miss, you aim for its lungs, then its intestines, because it won't run as far without proper respirations, and it will bleed out if you shoot it in the intestines.

I hope this helps you understand this game better.

reviewText: This is easily the worst game i've ever had the displeasure of playing. Putting aside the fact that it looks like absolute garbage compared to the trailers, the controls are easily the worst i've EVER had to attempt to use, and even after changing them to controls i'd be used to, it's still just so slow and clunky and uncomfortable to play. I spent the entirety of my time avoiding Utahraptors, literally just walking fast enough that they couldn't catch up to me, and not being able to do anything but continue walking away from them. I started out with a Bow, but no arrows, and i lost that useless bow as soon as i died from that Utahraptor relentlessly biting at me. The sprint bar goes down extremely fast, with practically no real speed bonus, and only recharges at an acceptable rate when you're standing still. I wandered around for about what i'd say was a mile, being attacked by several Utahraptors along the way, and saw nothing at all worth my time. No other dinosaurs, no weapons, nothing to interact with other than rocks and dino ♥♥♥♥, literally just those ♥♥♥♥ing Utahraptors. Altogether, I'd have to say that i wasted $30, and i really wish that i could refund this steaming pile of dogshit. All i can really think is that this game was thrown together by a couple of Jurrasic Park wannabe-fanatics with 0 talent in 3D modeling and animation. Truly pathetic. 1/10

reviewText:
I played for a while. The map size is definitely a highlight, well done to the devs for such a huge map.
This advantage is also its weakness. It takes up to an HOUR to travel a fair distance, and with no other transport but your feet, there is no way to speed this up. On the way, you will probably get killed by dinosaurs.

If you find a gun, you're forced to reload the game of risk of losing said gun, and it restocks ammo. Basically, you must restart your game to get ammo. Grinding, really.

Using this logic, in order to PROGRESS you need to GRIND.
Also, the game itself feels unfinished, it feels like an alpha or beta staged game. They need to develop the game more and find a new way of progressing without grinding.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

By far the least buggest, most incredibly fun Early Access game I've played so far.

The AI is actually really clever as the T-Rex was stalking around trying to find me and once it spotted me, it was freaking scary. Graphics could uses some work but my goodness the Dinosaur models are AMAZING!

Gameplay is really good but I would like the ability to recover my health by either drinking the water or being able to open up the dinos and eat their meat, something like that would be great for a future update.

All in all, this game is great for anyone who is getting bored with DayZ and wants a new experience in the world of Survival Games.

Early Access of this game gets a 8.9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fun game so far. Some definite quality of life improvements would include: stackable ammo, option to pause game, markers for your corpse on every death (not just your most recent death), reduce sounds of mushrooms.
It's only in early access. I'd imagine some more game mechanics such as missions should be added to give a person a goal to keep playing.

Weapons would be nicer to come across a little more often. Items such as treestands, blinds, bait, would be nice. I haven't come across anything like that yet. Night vision goggles would be tight. Maybe stuff like avatar and weapon customization would be nice. Also if you die and can't get back to your corpse without quitting the game, you shouldn't lose all of your stuff. There should be some way to get it back.

Another nice feature would be skills that level up such as endurance, stealth, accuracy, etc. You would gain points by killing dino's that could be spent on level ups.

Anyway, just my thoughts. Having fun getting molested by Utahraptors. 21/10, would get molested again.

reviewText: Based on a hunting game, theHunter Primal's dinosaurs are all very detailed and have truly awesome accompanying sound effects. The gun play is very realistic feeling and the game's mechanics demand players be a marksman or face being eaten. Playing something like a survival game at first players must search the map for gear and weapons while being hunted by Velociraptors, Tyrannosaurs Rex, and Quetzalcoaltlus.   There is no crafting, you only need manage your health, clothing, weapon, and ammo.  Once you have leveled up with points accumulated from kills you can spawn in with better equipment and the game becomes more hunting orientated, less survival orientated.  Be warned this game can be a bit of a walking simulator and despite being both beautiful and terrifying the AI leaves a little something to be desired. theHunter Primal is definitely worth it in sale, the game continues to see new developer made content and supports both cooperative and PvP game modes.

reviewText:
Hello, my name is Blackmagix95, and this is my review on TheHunter: Primal. I been playing this game ever since it was early access, and judging from my experience with the game, I recommend this game ONLY to people with a lot of patience and a sense of intelligence. Besides, most of the bad reviews on this game were made by players who played less than 30 hours or gave up on the game because the developers were barely adding content, even though they were working on new games like Mad Max or Just Cause 3. TheHunter: Primal is also nowhere near a survival game. It is more of a hunting stimulator, but with dinosaurs. If you really want a dinosaur survival game, go to freakin ARK. Last thing I want to see on the game's community discussions is more ARK favoritism and hateful rants.

Anyway, when I played the game at launch, I did had some terrible experiences with TheHunter Primal, but eventually I managed to learn from my mistakes and applied them to my skills.
It is true, this is game is hard for new players but it is part of the learning process and requires patience. Once you begin the game, it is recommended that you find a group of people to hunt with, especially if one of them has experience with the game, but ASK FIRST. It is also important to put time into the game in order to have a basic idea on the game's mechanics and to understand the strengths/weaknesses of certain guns/weapons, the dinosaurs and their AI functions/behaviors, the hunting advantages/disadvantages in certain environments, and what parts of a dinosaur's body is best to shoot at. And lastly, do expect to walk a lot; the map layout is pretty big and there are some momemts where you don't run into many dinosaurs. That is where patience and intelligence is needed.

If you can't dedicate the time to learn from the game, too impatient, or lack basic common sense, DON'T BUY THIS GAME. I used to join groups when I was a noob, but now I can solo-hunt with just a bow, a .44 magmum revolver and a machete/hatchet.

Also, there are a lot of guides made to help new players out, and most of us pro-players are willing to provide tips/tricks for the game. Take advantage of them. Who knows... perhaps someday I may run into one of you new players. Do expect me to hunt naked since I got rid of all of my noble clothing to get more inventory space for stuff. DON'T DO THIS STUNT UNLESS YOU UNDERSTAND THE DINOSAURS. YOU WILL BE DINNER!

reviewText: Thehunter: Primal has all the potential to be a great, awesome game in many regards. You hunt and explore alone or with other survivors (multi-player) and are also hunted by the creatures of this game. Experiences can make you feel horrified if you forget your actually playing a game to some. What started out as a mega promising game fell to the wayside with no updates or patches for almost a year. A NEW DLC has been released with some new fixes along with a great mission to kill the Primal Queen T-Rex. You must first seek out the rare T-Rex and aquire its gland to lure the Primal Queen|' out into the open. She is must stronger than the normal Rex's found within the game.  New high tech weapons are gifted to the players skilled enough to bring down the Primal Queen.  A new survey for players was put out by Expansive Worlds asking numerous questions about future things that could possibly make the game better. New DLC's and such. There are some bugs still noticably found in the game that are said to be fixed soon. Hopefully the Devs are now onboard with this project permanently and can give us tons of new explorations
date: more creatures to horrify the faint of heart. The game deserves to be updated and new materials added frequently even if it means spending money on new DLC's by its fanbase. There are not many Dino games out there that are worth anyones time. This one has the potential to be a great one. Great game
recommended: needs some Dev love before it loses its fanbase and is lost forever. Time will tell if the effort is put into it. We hope so......"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pretty basic game as it stands at the moment. Always liked the idea of a game like this. The nuts and bolts of it are that you are dropped into a prehistoric world filled with three dinosaur types as of this review in which your score is based upon how many you take down sucessfully. You start with basic gear which includs a bow and arrow. I do like the bow and arrow idea however I thought it a little simple considering you're race has mastered interstella travel but yet you start with a bow and arrow...Perhaps it would be better to start with a bow that at least resembles your current state in evolution and not made of simple wood, maybe some type of carbon fibre similar to the ones featured in Crysis 3.

The graphics seem decent at the higher settings, sound is also of a satifactory quality, would be nice if the T-Rex sounded like the Jurrasic Park one's though. The animals behaviour is slightley weird at the moment, you are pretty much invisible if you lie down, not that that makes much difference as you can hardly kill things with your starting gear. One thing i did really like it that fact that if you score hits on the animal you can follow their blood trail to their piont of death with arrows stuck in them. Unfrotunatley at this time it seems you cannot retreive arrows which is sad because ultimatley thats what makes a bow a good choice of weapon.

Below are a list of things

- Better dinasaur sounds
- retreivable arrows
- different types of arrows
- better looking bow
- craftables.
- some sort of black market to sell skins for better gear
- bigger vegatation and trees, the trees are too small for the time period its depicting.
- Packs or heards of more dinasaur types roaming.
- Would like to see dinosaur AI and own survival nature, IE all dinosaurs should get hungry and look for food, the    herbavurs should eat and drink as well as the carnivors. dinosaurs should stay in packs (mainly the herbavaurs) In essence i would love to see a whole echo stystem in place before any player is put in the mix.
- In talking echo balances I would like to see dinosaures who have nests as they did, if you stuumbled on a T-rex nest you may well find an angry mother and/or father around which would give the game more depth. Would like to see the young ones as well as a apart of tracking and of fear as if you spotted a lone young T-rex you'd be sure his perents wern't to far away and could cry for its mother (similar to Jurrasic Park The Lost World)
- I want the feeling of being a hunter, but at the same time i want to feel like im being activley hunted sometimes.

over all a very basic game at the moment but if they add depth such as creating a pre historic echo system they may well find they have a great hunting game here.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For an early access game, theHunter: Primal is satisfactory. Not the best, but certainly not the worst.

The main draw of the game is survivng on an island full of dinosaurs which is a ton of fun. Although the dinosaurse's AI is mediocre at best, the thrill of being hunted by a pack of raptors or chased by a T-Rex is pretty terrifying. The scenery and sound effects are extremely impressive, adding life to a massive jungle world, which gives the illusion that the animals are talking to one another.

Unfortunately there is not much to do but make your way across the island, hunting for loot while the combat and weapon options are limited.

As it stands at the time of this review, I only recommend it if you have close friends to enjoy it with. That being said, if the development of this game continues at a reliable pace, theHunter: Primal has the potential to be a great game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Most realistic hunting enviroment I've played in to date.  Awesome game physics and highly detailed landscapes and dinosaurs make for a thrilling hunting experience.  An air of caution to those easily scared. Do not play in the dark with headphones.

The experience starts you off in a space capsule that lands on a planet filled with blood thirsty dinosaurs.  Your main objective is to hunt, kill and rid the island of these man eating beasts.  You start off with a bow and few arrows to tide you over unitl you eventually find crates scattered around the map, containing different weapons and ammo.  When encountering these larger that life beasts, I recommend you use the environment to your advantage.  There's plenty of undergrowth to conceal yourself until the perfect shot presents itself to you.

As an early release for $19.00, you get more than you pay for.  You'll find the plush and vibrant island environment and a variety of three Dinosaurs, anough to contend with until further developement.  The targets include the infamous Utahraptor, T-Rex and Triceratops.  As developement continues, more dinosaurs will be added along with more objectives i'm sure.  This is a single/multiplayer interface where you can either go it alone, or team up with others.

Power in numbers!!

And good hunting.....

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I would easily give this game of the year award but atm, it crashes wayyyyy to often. I was hosting a game of 15 people and my client crashed. So many people get dissapointed when playing. It's a pain really, but IT'S WORTH IT. It's seriously so much fun that i've given up on all other games. Getting stalked across the landbridge by a pack of raptors, getting eaten by a t-rex that comes out of nowhere, taking selfies with triceratops that got their head stuck in a hill. What more can you want?

Remember that you actually need to aim on vital areas of the animals. If you shoot head on you're likely to be eaten. I hit a raptor from the front 4 times with shotgun slugs, but it still ate me, but you can one-shot them with bow and arrow if you hit straight in the heart! Taking down a t-rex on your own is not impossible. They are afraid of walking down really steep hills, so if you find a ledge, it's easy to get a few shots on the rex to make it start running away, then you pick out your marksman rifle and take it down but this game is best if you play it with friends.

Map knowledge is key. There some settlements spread across the map where you can find various firearms. If you find a settlement, write down the coordinates, which you can find in the hand computer.

Buildings: I want there to be more sophisticated ruins or buildings. There are towers and runied forts but there are no doors or you can't enter any of the old buildings. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having put a few hours into this game with a group from 2 to 5 people, I have mixed feelings about this game. I love the concept, but in it's current state, the game mechanics make it near impossible to survive for any prolonged amount of time.

One very large issue is with running and (the lack of) jumping. I understand the point of the game is slow movement and tracking, but that doesn't always work. Particularly when a T-Rex comes wandering by. Maybe I haven't figured out what draws their attention yet, but at this point, it seems like merely being in their presence brings them right to you no matter your actions. And once they are onto you, it's nearly impossible to get away thanks to the movement mechanics. Being able to run in something like 15-second burts, and otherwise having to walk everywhere is not realistic in any sense, and makes evasion impossible. Even someone massivly out of shape can run for longer than 15 seconds before being winded, so there's no reason why a group of fit looking hunters shouldn't. I'm all for stamina, and having prolongued running affect your ability to shoot or something would be great. But basically not being able to run as a means of evasion when you end up in a fight you cannot win, that makes the game seriously fustrating.

Also, the T-Rex seems to sort of have a homing ability. In several instances with multiple players, a T-Rex has killed one of us, only to ingore the other players and instead head in a straight path directly where the player respawned, sometimes several hundred meters away. I don't know if this is a glitch or not (I really hope so), but it is also fustrating to spawn into the game with a T-Rex already zoned in to come find you and kill you.

Those two issues aside, the game really is very tense, and a lot of fun. I see a lot of potential here. I hope that the two issues above are a result of bugs or experimentation, and not perminant gameplay mechnanics.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Original article with a hilarious picture of a dino with four arrows sticking out of his head here: http://rgz.ca/gaming/thehunter-primal-preview-a-promising-amorphously-designed-game/

I’ve been playing theHunter for quite some time. Once a year, I throw in my yearly subscription and it allows me to pick up a gun or bow and go patiently wait for deer, bears, elk, and more to come close enough to shoot. Other than the fact that you’re shooting animals, it’s an almost calming experience. A relaxing, slow simulation that still allows you to feel accomplished over the course of a single hunt.

As you can imagine, I was pretty excited when I saw theHunter: Primal. theHunter is already a great hunting simulation with some impressive AI and gorgeous scenery. It’s also regularly updated and, even now, is still getting new animals every so often. There’s also not much risk in the base game, though. Sure, a boar could maul you but you can jump right back in with all your stuff intact. You don’t die. You’re just “injured.” This new edition could very easily have become the prehistoric Cabela’s Dangerous Hunts of the series.

Then I read the store page a little more. Worry set in. Rather than being a new edition of theHunter, the game seemed to want to take the core gameplay and underlying technology and make something closer to a futuristic version of The Stomping Land, sans dino-wrangling. PvP was the first alarm. Then I read about “survival” and “permadeath” features. It was starting to sound a bit like something I didn’t really want.

Fortunately, it isn’t as bad as it may sound. It is still very much theHunter. theHunter with a bizarre, vague story, futuristic setting, and dinosaurs thrown in, but theHunter, nonetheless. I didn’t personally try out PvP so it would be hard to give an opinion on how that works – I didn’t even come in contact with Kat during the time we were playing – but the basic gameplay is there. I would be surprised if it weren’t. There’s an acclaimed game that it’s being built on.

You can tell, too. The basic AI behavior is there. Raptors hunt in packs, with the occasional raptor scouting ahead and then returning to the group. Tyrannosaurs shake the ground as they walk, and will often pay no mind to you unless you make yourself very obvious. Triceratops are generally more peaceful and won’t bother with you.

It isn’t all there, though. I experienced a number of problems with the AI, mostly pertaining to raptors. I mean, triceratops paying no mind to the tyrannosaurs that are coming right at them, shaking the ground as they go, and then bolting at the first sign of your tiny human self makes no sense to me but it’s more of a design flaw than an issue with the AI, and one that was probably carried over from the more peaceful creatures in theHunter. I was even used to animals that hopelessly walk into rocks repeatedly, hoping to finally get past them, having experienced many issues like it in the original game. No, my problems run deeper.

Raptors work perfectly fine – until they become aware of you. Then they break. Not all the time, mind you, but they are broken pretty easily and there have been several ways in which I’ve experienced them breaking. The most frustrating is when you’re being chased. They do this awkward thing where they will attack you and then stop, wait for the animation to finish, and continue to sit there, as if “getting their bearings.” They can’t attack you and move at the same time. They don’t jump at you in any sort of way or pin you down. They just run up to you and come to a full stop when attacking. As if this didn’t break immersion enough, with raptors repeatedly falling yards behind you only to suddenly start running after you again, if you save your stamina until you’re attacked bolt towards the nearest brush without looking back, and dive into it, there is a high chance you can escape a raptor. You know, a raptor that is faster than you and was chasing you.

That’s not all that is wrong with them, though. Sometimes, when you are in areas with a lot of cover, and you dive into cover, raptors will still know where you are – sort of. They run at you…and then proceed to stand over you, turn at a ninety degree angle to you and just sit there. If you move, there’s a 50-50 chance it will fix them and they will kill you. If you don’t move, there’s about a ten percent chance that they will lose interest and walk off. Yes, you read that right. Raptors that know you’re there will sometimes randomly walk off rather than killing you. However, the most hilarious encounter I had with one of them occurred when it knew I was there, so it ran around an entire group of trees, sideways the entire time, making me think I was safe before showing up right next to me, facing a different direction without moving.

It’s not like you can really take advantage of this, either. The bow is very, very hard to use, requiring exacting precision in the right places to take anything down. No, headshots don’t work. I’ve tried. I should have known better, being someone who plays theHunter, a hunting simulation, meaning you should, as you do in real life, aim for the lungs and heart, but I tried anyways. The result was a hilarious four arrows sticking out of the raptor’s head as it sat there, not killing me.

However, the biggest problem is hinted at in the article title. Right now, it’s just a bit of an amorphous blob of awkward game design. More like a mod for theHunter than anything, a testing bed for ideas as they throw dinosaurs in and try to figure out how the community wants them to do things. It’s very much theHunter. Other than losing everything when you die, which doesn’t exactly feel like you’ve lost much currently, it is very much not a survival game. Not yet, at least. At the same time, though, just enough has changed to make it feel less meaningful than theHunter. By introducing survival aspects, it’s not about killing the biggest dino or having the most successful hunt. It’s about survival. But theHunter isn’t and, right now, at least, it’s sitting in this spot where just enough has changed that it doesn’t scratch the same itch as theHunter but it isn’t changed enough to warrant not just playing theHunter.

It’s fortunate, then, that the game is buy-to-play, rather than a hybrid of subscription and free-to-play models. You can buy Primal once during Early Access and never have to worry about any other fees. If you’re an existing fan of theHunter, regardless of what happens, you will probably get your money’s worth through the joy of hunting dinosaurs using their existing hunting model before inevitably going back to theHunter while you wait for them to sort everything out. Don’t worry, you can turn off PvP and make it a dino hunting marathon. If you’re a fan of survival games that incorporate PvP, however, I would wait a while. The mechanics to make it one aren’t all there yet and it’s a bit unclear of where they’re going to go from here. It shows promise for both ends of the spectrum but it needs a bit of time to find itself first.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great Game! Harldy any bugs for Alpha, those it does crash now and then (fortunately that's at the game menu when starting not half way through a hunt) It's a slow paced game but a highly rewarding one and the encounters with the Dinosaurs I'd describe as more frequent than the original Hunter game, and perfectly balanced between realism and entertainment.
If you don't think properly when you start you may not enjoy the game, you cannot aimlessly roam on your own with a bow and expect to live. I teamed up with someone else so if we did encounter a Raptor before we got a gun, we'd both have a good chance at taking it down together. Gradually you build up your weapons and ammo, and now I'm roaming around taking everything out. The introductions of pvp optional servers give you more to shoot at for impatient gamers, but also dents your survivability as often people gift you guns in non pvp.
I'd recommend viewing the forums for a 'base map' - there are 25 so far in the game and if you know where they are you can enter the game and run to the base in the hope of getting a big gun. I'm now kitted out in full camo gear, i have a sniper and scope rifle, and a shotgun. It's really, really fun, especially seeing the holes you can blast out the dinosaurs with the rifle. I'm totally impressed and what a bargain at 15.99 for the hours I've now put in (16), I can't wait to see what else is added as the game develops - a really throroughly good effort.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This new error 16002 where you can't connect to the game is not good.  19 days not being able to play now so still thumbs down. Other than that I like the game lots of fun playing with friends.  No comments from the Devs in the forums also not looking very good.

(edit)   Well I had to edit my review finally after some updates I was able to play again.  There are still some issues that need to be addressed 1. in multiplayer if your not the host your shots are not counting when shooting animals.  So if you shoot 30 times into a T-rex and your friend shoots 30 times only his shots count.  Same with the other animals as well.  2. The shotgun has issues off and on with the different ammo types, have to take the shotgun out of the slot place it into inventory then replace it back into weapon slot.  Was killed because of this 3 or 4 times.  Also sometimes the shotgun doesn't want to fire not sure what is causing this but it does happen.  3. The power of the ammo doesn't seem to be strong enough at times one time it drops everything no problem.  Then other times its like you have to shoot for example T-rex 60 times to kill it point blank something wrong with that.  First came out I was able to get a T-rex with 4 to 10 shots not anymore.  4. The grouping of dinos odd load ratios.  Raptors seem to be in larger packs of 7 to 9 more often now.  Triceratops seem to be in groups of 3 to 6 .  If your unlucky like me at times you get the 3 and 4 T-rex at one time.  Most of the time can get 1 maybe 2 of them but then the other 2 get you.  The ammo stacking has made things alot nicer able to have ammo with no worries now.  Still kinda buggy at times with it but not as bad.  Now comes the weather I was dreading the day when the rain from hell would hit the game.  I do not care for the rain system had it in the regular thehunter game.  Is way too loud needs to have a way to lower the sound level.  Try playing this game with headphones in TS when it rains you can't hear anyone and it gives you a headache.  I haven't tried pvp yet first off I don't want to lose the clothing it took me days to find.  I really would like to have a second game profile so I could have one for the regular game play and one for PVP play. That way I wouldn't care if I lost what I had when in PVP etc.  Other than that I like the game nothing like the ROAR of the mighty T-rex .  Then the foot steps the screen shake then  the first sight of the Mighty Rex.  You hide where ever you can it walks past you then suddenly stops and sniffs the air. Your heart races you wonder do I shoot or do I stay still.  50/50 chance I say go for it.  I would now have to recommend this game now as I do hope they keep updating with goodies.  I say 8 out of 10  as it is now.   After more things are added I will see about updating my review and see if it should get a better score.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even in early access this game feels polished.

The dinos act how you would expect them to. They are challenging and feel natural. The environment is huge! so there is plenty of time to expore and get a feel for the place. You might not encounter a dino right away but the suspense really keeps you on your toes. Especially when youre in a dense forest and they are camoflaged so well (another reason I love the realism of this game).

A few times I thought I had avoided a raptor then came face to face with one or more only to realize they were hunting me. When you hear them and cant see them you really get a sense of F**K I'm going to die.

For rougly half an hour I had to camp in some ferns and wait for a female raptor to move away. I had to listen for a call to know where she was so I could scurry to more cover. In reality if dinos were real I feel this game nails it. I dont care that I had to wait half an hour to escape the raptor because it felt like she hunting me. Later I lured her to my hiding spot and murdered her in cold blood (she got a couple bites in the process). The thrill of killing a raptor is awesome and the kicker of getting to take a trophy shot is just the icing on the cake.

There are definately some things I would like to see in the finished versions like more herbivors and carnivores of carivous sizes etc even pterosaurs would be aweome! Aside from what I want if the developers continue to provide polished content there is no reason not to get this game especially if you love dinosaurs.

There is so much potential for this game. I can only hope they flesh it out with a greater variety of wildlife to make the island really feel alive (it already does but what I mean is more so).

I am happy I did. I hope that with more people buying this they can push out more content faster.

This game litterally drops you in the middle of no where with a bow and arrow a GPS tracker and thats it. For a game to do that it has to be good and this one is. I can't praise it enough.

If you buy it don't expect a finished product but do buy it to help this game reach full release. Its awesome.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hard to fairly review an early access game.  As it stands, the game needs more.  And not more dinosaurs, it needs more layers of strategy, more training up of the hunter you play, etc.  If it doesn't gain more depth, I'd give it a bad review because the replay value isn't there like the standard theHunter" game.

But I'm not sure why some people are calling for more dinosaurs.  It's a hunting game
date: not a shoot-the-fish-in-the-barrel game.  And when one of the dinosaurs starts hunting YOU
recommended: you'll be more than a little grateful for the low population count.\n\nThe concept of a hunting game where sometimes the prey hunts you in a semi-realistic setting (doesn't the most recent research indicate that dinosaurs had feathers?) is a wonderful concept.  This game oozes potential through every pore

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hi people.

My first look about this game:

I start the game and the first look is great, a very good world with many variants, very nice sound and a sensation of fear. I start to explore and i have my first dinossaur, a female raptor calling. Is great, but i only have a bow with 5 arrows. Ok, i need a rifle or something better to kill this lady, then i move 200m and i see a T-Rex, he make a creapy call and i try to get back slowly, but i have the lady in my back. Ok, i die... I get in again and in a few minutes i get my firt kill, a triceratops.
This is a early version of the game, and we know is a lot of work comming, but now is alredy a good game.

Problems:

This game is great, but have a few problems.

- The volume of the T-Rex call is very low.
- When a dinossaur (triceratops) go for a hole in the midle of the clifs, he stuck in there and you shoot at 3m, he dont run and dont see you.
- So many dinossaurs in the map (i realise is because we have only 3 species yet) is very dificult to move without step in a carnivor.
- Not the call, but the noise of a triceratops (presence noise), looks like a carnivor in my opinion. The call is perfect.
- To many crashes on the servers.

I'm a big fan of TheHunter and now of TheHunter: Primal and for Expansive Worlds and all the people envolved in this game, thanks for this great game, nice work.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a fan of theHunter this game is great! As an early access title there is still not much to hunt, you have the choice of 3 dinosaurs all with unique AI and attitudes. What this game does really well is the sense of how epic these animals truly are, going up against a T-rex alone is truly a deathwish most of the time, you're going to need some perfectly placed shots to take it down. PVP servers also add to the chaos, with full-loot pvp you can trust no one in this world and it leaves for a very Jurassic Park-like survival game. The loot system is very dry and could be improved and of course dinosaur selection can be expanded but I'm sure that will come.

Overall 8/10 and easily a 9 by release.

reviewText: Starts out fairly hard, it's easy to die and it takes awhile to find the weapons you need to take down the big stuff.  It's a fun game if you can get past those parts. It's easier if you join a group and hunt together since you can cover each other. Shot placement is extremely important; try to hit them in the heart.  Well worth the 7.49 I paid for it on the Steam Summer Sale.  Now that I've got good weapons, it's hard to quit playing. I've had the game crash a few times but haven't lost my gear because of it.  If you die (and the server is still running) you can go back to where your body lies and gather up all your gear.  If you like a challenging hunting sim with dinosaurs where the hunter can become the hunted, then you will like this game.

reviewText:
EDIT(Sept14th2015): This review was made with high hopes, but the devs have since moved their focus to other projects, and much of my happy vision will never be realized. Nonetheless, it's a good game and it's actively maintained at the moment.

First off, let me clarify: this is NOT a survival game. As long as you don't walk off a cliff or get torn limb from limb by a dinosaur, you'll live forever.

So then what is it? Well I have seen two ways of playing this game.  You can play it as an exploration game, full of emergent narratives and fantastic vistas waiting to be seen by those willing to tread the most dangerous paths. Or, you can play it as a hunting game, full of big things to kill with your big gun and get money and a fancy dead trophy.  I am aware that the game is being designed with the latter in mind. But emergence is one of the truly wondrous elements of the video game as a narrative medium.  New and unanticipated things happen when your audience is also your performer and your performance.

You have probably guessed by now which play style I embrace.  I have ZERO interest in game hunting, dinosaur or otherwise.  I am, however, interested in walking among dinosaurs, as I have dreamed of fondly ever since that childhood  trans-Atlantic flight I spent reading a National Geographic book about them cover to cover, and I apparently was so adorably excited about the whole thing that the pilot gave me his Lufthansa captain's pin and patted me on the head.  More so than any other game I've played, this game allows me to do that.

Dinosaurs and man, two species separated by 65 million years of evolution have just been suddenly thrown back into the mix together. How can we possibly have the slightest idea what to expect? -Dr Alan Grant
Luckily you have me to tell you a little bit about what to expect. The very limpid premise to justify your simultaneous existence with dinosaurs is that you are a scout selected to spearhead a colonization effort on this alien Eden."  Isn't it a little chilling that we are presumably doing this by enacting the mass slaughter of the native fauna? There's some commentary there
date: intended or otherwise.\n\nLike I said at the beginning
recommended: this is not a survival game.  There are no hunger or thirst mechanics.  There's a fairly typical stamina bar depleted by sprinting or melee but quickly recharged.  There is food out there in the wilds to be scavenged
hoursPlayed: but despite its realistic appearance it's arcade food: eat it to restore health.  Scavenging rather than crafting is your main way of acquiring weapons and equipment.  There are busted colony pods
voteText: half-finished bunkers
helpfulPercent: and the well-supplied bodies of many a less fortunate colonist scattered throughout the landscape.  Early on this will be your only source of gear that *might* protect you when you accidentally cross upwind of that T-Rex you've been tracking.  But more likely you will join the broken bodies of the brave stacked up for carrion (to paraphrase Homer).\n\nPlaying as an explorer is indeed punctuated by intense action.  I will shoot a dinosaur to save myself. I will flail my gun around in terror as I hear but can't see the pack of utahraptors close in on me. I will use my machete to hack aside the velociraptor lunging my jugular.  When you kill and catalog a dinosaur you get money and experience based on its rarity
votesHelpful: its difficulty to kill
votesTotal: and the integrity of the corpse (prohint: you won't get much for blasting a campysaur with you shotty).  Every time you perish you are brought to a shop screen where you can purchase gear.  The availability of different items is a function of both your xp level and your accumulated capital.  Slowly but surely you get to a point where you can survive most run-ins with smaller dinosaurs on your own.  If you plan to take on a T-Rex or if you want to blast a herd of peaceful triceratops for no reason
votesFunny: hop on a multiplayer server and team up.  Your character is persistent across servers
commentsCount: but taking down a Tyrannosaur (possibly to protect those innocent triceratops) requires well coordinated tactical engagement. Still most of you will die. It's glorious.\n\nI continue to thoroughly enjoy this game.  The crass masculinity infecting the multiplayer chat can be irritating
column16: but it's not game-ruining
column17: and frankly when is it not asserting itself with knuckles dragged and chests bumped in whatever multiplayer chat you find.  The graphics are beautiful
column18: gameplay is challenging and the shooting mechanics are fairly realistic.  The dino AI gets better with every update.  They really will sniff you out if your upwind and enact coordinated assaults complete with feints to draw your attention while they flank.  It's wondrous.\n\nIf you are now or ever were a dinosaur nerd
column19: this game is essential.  Highly recommended."

reviewText:
I have played the orginal Hunter for many years now on and off since it was very new and in beta phase, and it always brings me back. Sadly, the same can not be said for The Hunter Primal. The graphics are great and alot of the animals look real enough (I dont know fully as I have never seen a T Rex in the flesh) but its let down by a very clunky old style engine, It is what The Hunter was using in the original beta from the feeling. The Animals charge you, then sort of mill around doing nothing for 2-3 seconds before running off and charging again.

My other couple of gripes with this that annoy the hell out of me, is the weapons and gear factor, unlike The Hunter you dont have an account with all your gear saved to it. Its what you had on you when you last logged out, This is fine, apart from when it bugs out and you lose what you have, Or worse yet, due to personal hosting, If you die and are running back to your corpse to get your gear, and they decide to log out. Bye bye gear. Meaning you start from scratch again and have a near impossible task of trying to open some containers with ammo and weapons in. Its crazy you have to be level 10 to even buy your first gun.

The Quetzalcoatlus are far too OP, they are a nightmare to try and kill and bug out constantly, with a werid flying animation. The Dino noises can be heard from so far away that they sound like they are on top of you when actually they are 500 metres away.

My honest advice is to save the money you would pay for this, go to The Hunter, pay for a 3 month bundle and play that, its so much more fun, its not hunting dinosaurs, but a bear can make you just as dead as any T Rex.

reviewText:
I also received this game in a bundle. I honestly think it was part of a bundlestars bundle.
When i received it i rolled my eyes abit, as most of my bundles I get from friends after I pick them up a game or two we kinda buy games for one another to try as a group. I saw the reviews and they seemed absolutely attrocious.
Fast forward to playing this game. Asides from your items not saving on your person when the server gets shut down. I really, like the suspense in this game. Sure it's got afew developement glitches and optimization issues that could probably be resolved. So here are some of my pro's and cons.
Pro:
-Tracker is awesome, as well as your ability to see tracks and the estimated time the tracks were made.
-The suspense when hunting a T-Rex is incredible, they don't auto run to you. Instead they sniff you out if your laying down and they've caught your scent.
-Raptors will attack you, but if you fight them off they will dip, for self preservation.
-Dino's will hunt one another.

Cons
-Some A.I.'s will occassionally glitch out(story: after two-three hours i fired afew round into a raptor that wasn't moving... i unloaded into it afew more rounds... it didn't die. I walked up to it...nothing)
-No graphics settings, what you see when you log in is what you get.
-Server's are host-player based and rarely Server, server based.
-Zero PVP.

All around it's pretty fun. I certainly wouldn't buy it for full price inless improvement's are made. But if you see it on sale or pick it up on a bundle. Try this game. Alot of these reviews are just twelve yearolds spreading the usual internet cancer.

reviewText:
Intro-                                                                                                                                                                                             theHunter Primal is a hunting survival style sim for steam. You can hunt alone or with friends on a large prehistoric island map. You search for weapons and clothing with hungry T-Rex's and other dinosaurs stalking the large area.Will you be the hunter or the prey..

Pros-                                                                                                                                                                                      Graphically it seems to be nice looking
You hunt mostly dangerous dinosaurs with a range of weapons
Nice large continent map to travel
Sounds design is nice and atmospheric
The difficulty is just right to have you feeling helpless when chased

Cons-                                                                                                                                                                                             There is a somewhat limited amount of clothes or gear to pick from
No vehicles on map so you will need to do alot of walking or running
Some dinosaurs especially the T-Rex can take way too much damage                                                                                      Perhaps more dinosaur variety is needed for this game
There is only the one map no matter if its size is large                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 .......................................................................................................................................................................................My Final Thoughts-                                                                                                                                                                        While this game can give the player a good feeling of a realistic hunting experience,being replaced with dinosaurs.This is a game needing perhaps patience and or friends as a group to keep it interesting and fun.This game seems to be quite well developed having a somewhat active player base and dedicated servers at the moment.So overall a good game for the more patient and hardcore hunter among you.Hope this helps,thanks.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I say a positive recommendation because this game has great potential.

Beginning with nothing but a self made bow and 5 arrows, you must trek across a massive island hunting and being hunted by two types of prehistoric dinosaurs, utahraptors and the mighty t-rex. These are not the only dinosaurs, there is also the ever illusive triceratops. This is my only real criticism, with such a huge amount of background available, there are only three trackable, huntable, lethal dinosaurs to be found in this massive island. That being said, the game is tense, rewards exploration and if you're into big game hunting,the game doesn't get much bigger.

Less so however is the inclusion of modern paleantology, the dinosaurs in this game don't have feathers for instance. But I doubt if this really matters much, the game gives the classic hunting dinos of Jurassic Park feel. Lots of fun.

reviewText: I cannot recommend a game that was built as a side project by the devs of The Hunter, and then seemingly abandoned by them a few months later after they milked the steam community for $20 something dollars.  We only see updates once every few months now and they dont fix the fundamental problems of the game.  This is listed as a survival game, that they are 100% correct on.  They dont give you enough ammo to survive on so you either spend all your time trying to sneak around the dinosaurs which usually end up sniffing you out no matter how well camoflauged you are and you end up wasting your precious ammo on trying to kill them because the devs dont add enough ammo in the boxes they spawn in that you are supposed to use to keep yourself stocked up on.  There are numerous bugs and glitches that they need to fix and in order to survive you usually see people exploiting them just to get enough ammo to survive, that or you spend all your time throwing yourself off cliffs to buy" ammo which is only purchasable in your death screen.  There arent enough dinosaur varieties in the game
date: especially herbivores and you never see the carnivores interact with the herbivores
recommended: they completely ignore each other for the most part no matter what is going on in-game.  There are a few "crown" or good camps that drop decent gear so expect to do nothing more in this game but running between those camps trying to outfit yourself enough to take down a rex and getting eaten many many times in the process.  If I had a dollar every time I screamed at my pc: "Devs
hoursPlayed: fix your game!"  I could replace my current setup with a triple SLI'd Titan GTX PC and go pick up ARK instead and run it at ultra and 60 fps."

reviewText: Great game. One of the best and most realistic dinosaur hunting sim ever. Great graphic, advanced and realistic A.I., dynamic weather and day-night cycle. Spectacular environment and an iteresting backstory that you can discover in details finding abandoned documents. Dinosaurs are scientifically and anatomically accurate. Even if there are only 5 species (yet), they are really balanced (Triceratops: herbivore population, very common. Tyrannosaurus: apex predator. Utharaptor: medium sized pack hunter. Velociraptor: small but dangerous, really funny to fight a pach of them. Quetzacoatlus: flying scavenger and small animal hunter). A must-have for anyone.

reviewText:
Contrary to what most may think after watching the promo videos, this game takes a LOT of patience, but definitely delivers the rush you'll get from the dino encounters.  Yes you're slow, and you can't sprint as long as you'd like.  But the stamina bar is plenty when utilized properly (even when you're face to face with a T-Rex), and if you're running around you have to pay attention to your surroundings or you will get rushed by raptors.  You have to listen for the distant noises that clue you in as to what lies ahead, and you have to watch the terrain and figure out where each dino likes to hang out at different times during the day.  The game definitely is not what you'd expect, but in a good way.  You can dodge a T-Rex and solo a pack of raptors, but there's plenty of learning to be had from trial and error.  But once you find out where to hit, you're twenty steps ahead of everyone else.

You will get frustrated.
You will get scared.
And you'll probably get bored at some point when you can't find a high powered gun.
Hang in there! :)

The in game experience requires patience, but so does the development of the game.  No, despite what steam says, it's not a finished product.  There is still much more that needs to be either fixed or implemented into the current game.

And yes, the game is so much more enjoyable with a friend or two, especially if you have something like Ventrilo, Skype, or Team Speak.  Especially when you get jumped by two T-Rex because you're buddy decided to shoot a Triceratops from 200m out.... it's plenty rewarding for the average players when you somehow take them both down as a team, and then realize you're out of ammo :)

I highly recommend this game!  It's too soon to say don't buy it, if you're worried then wait for it to go on sale, but it's definitely a game worth watching in the mean time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In its current state the game is good, but not great. Its in Early Access and the devs are adding more dino types and game play tweaks so it should improve. Also the devs are active in the forums which is very good. The one thing that, for me stops it from being very good is the survival aspect, all this involves at the moment is just not being eaten by a dino. You are being asked to 'survive' but without any crafting abilities. So add some basic crafting elements, like crafting arrows from trees and dino feathers, health packs from the islands fauna and even teepee type structure made from dino skin and sticks, this would allow you to create a spawn point for the player. Expand on this and get your team to build some teepees together, then you've got a team camp to start your hunting from. If this kind of thing was added the game would be superb and should be on top of every dino hunters list. There are loot chest around the map which contain guns and ammo, but this feels like a 'cop-out' from providing any kind of true survival game mechanics.

EDIT: and whatever you do, dont, and I mean REALLY don't, under any circumstances mention the word 'ZOMBIE' mod in the forums because you will get Phlamed by the games narrow minded FANBOYS.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First and foremost TheHunter: Primal is a game, where you spend much time with running, walking, crawling and sneaking through jungle, bush, swamp and heathland. If you easy get bored by just exploring a natural enviroment, then you probably should stay away from this game.

For those who love it, to lurk, to seek and to hunt the game offers a dense atmosphere with peaks of exciting fights and shout-outs. It´s not a conventional Shooter. Here you can´t easily lock and load your weapon and rush into battle. Fast-paced action is a quick way to death at Primal Eden, the dino-island.

For me the most fun is to playing with a friend or at small groups. It is a way to range the woods without to many squat-behind-the-bush interludes. As a team you can protect each other and in addition it´s possible to check all the loot-camps efficiently.

An essentiall aspect of hunter tactics you should adopt quickly, is to scent out your prey early. Some players don´t care about observing the enviroment. They run through the jungle and some minutes later they find themselves in a middle of a raptor-pack. It´s possible to avoid a lot of dangerous and probably deadly situations, if you stay calm and canny. I think this is a way to prevent the frustration of getting killed again and again.

Hunter and prey quickly switch sides at Primal Eden. Be prepared to withdraw for the sake of survival.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While the game has a good concept (which is why I bought it) there are a lot of issues.

To start - you start with nothing but a machete, and you're supposed to go around finding better gear, but there is NO GOOD WAY TO STAY IN STEALTH AROUND DINOS. I can't hardly find my way up the freakin' volcano to the research center to get better gear without being killed by a dino that shouldn't of seen me. Prone does nothing, crouch does nothing, moving slow does, guess what? NOTHING

Then there's the 'store' to unlock and buy better starting gear. There is nothing telling you how to level, there is nothing telling you how to earn the stuff to purchase things (such as the bow) from the store. I can only assume that you have to kill dinos and get the trophy ones to gain xp and coins, but again, if found it IMPOSSIBLE to do this without the proper gear, which I found IMPOSSIBLE to gain.

There's also the fact that this is labeled as a survival game, which I indeed am in love with as a genre. Here's the thing, this isn't a survival game. This is a 'run around like a chicken with it's head cut off, falling off a cliff and dieing multiple time as you attempt to get gear to kill stuff' game. There is no crafting, there is no 'good' way to get the improved gear, you can't build a camp of any sort for any kind of protection. It's run, kill, run, kill, loot if you can, and try to SURVIVE the dinos, but there is no way to actually do this. It's not a survival game because you have to survive, it's a survival game if you have to survive WITH THE MEANS TO DO SO.

Lastly, maybe this game isn't just for me. I'll be honest here and admit that. I think I would enjoy it with the ability to craft better items, maybe some resource gathering? BUilding up a base camp for protection, make me need to eat and drink, or at the very least, GIVE ME GEAR AT THE START THAT WILL ACTUALLY HELP.

With these things being said, I'm giving it a down vote for the time. I understand it is still in development, and I understand that it's probably got a long way to go. The thing is that at this stage, I don't see an appeal to it, and don't recommend it to anyone that's looking for a fun game that they can acomplish something with. I'll revisit it in the future some time and see how it's going then, but for now, I'm deleting it, and not planning on checking in for a few months, hopefully it becomes worth the 20$ soon!

reviewText: For me, this is the best dino game to date! I love playing it, its a little hard on single player but that also makes it fun, and its a blast in mp. The graphics are great, physics are great, AIs are great, the team that runs it is great/amazing, I really cant say enough good things about the game and devs! This and thehunter, in my opinion, are two of the best games out there, they are both very well developed with a team that is constantly adding updates, new features, and killing bugs. I am trying to think of a few cons to add to this, but i currently don't have any, except I do really miss the original raptor skins, and while the new ones are nice I would still like to see the old ones sometimes! The thing about this game that i know receives criticism is that there is a lot of walking around, and if your not properly equipped, getting killed. It just takes a little bit of planning and if you can find a group of people that's the best, but when you start out you will probably die a lot while you learn the game, and this is totally ok!

reviewText:
This is a game about hunting dinosaurs. There's no real plot, it's just shoot dinosaurs. Which isn't all that bad, because it's fun. theHunter: Primal is, however, not perfect (shocking, right?)

Pros:
- Very immersive experience, makes you feel as if you really are in this savage world
- Beautiful Visuals
- Fun gameplay and intense gameplay
- Interesting currency and respawn system
- Dinosaurs can track you, giving a unique thrill of being hunted. This game can be scary at times.

Nuetral:
- OK netcode

Cons:
- Small variety of weapons and dinosaurs alike. Feels very limited
- Dinosaurs seem unkillable at times unless you hit them directly in a vital organ. Once, I unloaded 6 shotgun shells and a rifle round into the chest of a Utahraptor. Then proceeded to die.
- Takes FOREVER to get from one place to another based on how slow you walk, and how SNAIL-PACED your stamina recharges. Seriously, I should be able to run for longer than 10 seconds and I should be able to run again in at least a minute.
- Lack of dinosaur interaction. Tyrannosaurs walk past Trikes and the Trikes don't seem to care at all.
- Poor AI. You can just continue to walk a rex in circles by staying at his back leg.

Overall: 6/10

This game is fun and a cool idea, but it feels unfinished. The lack of variability and proper AI leads to this feeling like an Early Access game, the same title it just recently dropped for a full release.

reviewText: Hi Everyone! I bought this game 100% random & out of bordom to find something new to play. Both me & my friend bought the game, downloaded it and started playing @ the same time. A few good things about this game is that 1.) it will keep you busy and curious looking for new items to make you a better and more effective hunter. 2.) the hunt can quickly get difficult to keep you on your toes and making sure you are making every shot count.. but there is also some cons I have ran across while playing the game thus far, Like simple bugs in multiplayer as well.. But nothing too bad to really effect your gameplay too much. there is a leveling system in the game as well as a store in game asking you if you would like to buy items you can get in the world with coin that you get for hunting down and killing dinos! the thing that I find painful and boring is that there is no other way to travel.. Basically you will be walking and running.. Hiding and etc.. CONSTANTLY.. No fast travel, No swimming & no cars etc to help you get around faster and your stamina is horrible.. But, with a game that will have you constantly running I think they should make it last longer than it does.. Also something that really bothers me in this game is the fact that it is a survival hunting game, But yet you don't have to worry about food, shelter or etc.. so the game is NOT so in depth.. it's straight to the point here aim and take your shot and claim your beautiful new trophy, That is the 1 and only point to this game! if your looking for a more realistic and more in depth exsperince this game may not be for you, also there is no ability to build or craft ANYTHING.. and there is not really a big variaty of weapons here either.. But honestly it's something to play when your bored. so, the main question you may be wanting to know here is: is the game worth the $29.99 asking price... NO! Save your money.

reviewText:
The game may have little content as of now, but it is really fun if you take the time to enjoy it. The Island is beautiful and so are the dinosaurs, and it never gets old to shoot another dinosaur and claim it's corpse. People assume the developers are just abandoning their game, but people are also ***holes and don't seem to understand how things work. Developers are humans to, and they have lives outside of this, and if they want to work on another game for a little bit then let them, they will update this game more and it will become a much better game.

Now to talk about from my experience of the game. I love the game. I play it a lot, and especially when I am just wanting to relax, I can just walk around, because this game is a lot of walking. But it is not as bad as people say, and it is nice to not always have a dinosaur trying to murder your face. After playing a lot I have learned better ways to take down dinosaurs more efficiently which in my opinion just makes me feel so powerful and unstoppable... until a Trex eats me. When I die I do not get mad because its part of the game, and it was not the devs fault for me dying, they made these dinosaurs to do 1 thing and 1 thing only... to kill you. How would the game be anywhere near fun if the dinosaurs couldn't just murder you so quickly, it makes you have to think. When I play I see a lot of people who think they can just run up to a Rex and unload all their bullets into it randomly, then they die and get mad at the game. Thats not how it works. This game is also fun if you have friends, also makes the long walks a little less lonely.

All in all I really love this game, I just don't like people who get mad at games. I recommend this because with little stuff in it, it is a really good game and I can not wait for future updates.

reviewText:
If you have an interest in dinosaurs and shooting games, this is a definate purchase for you. I have played since early access and the game has improved slowly and steadily, to the point where there is a decent amount of content.

The learning curve is very steep for new players, even for a seasoned player losing all their gear and starting from scratch can be difficult. Don't let this put you off as the game offers many rewarding experiences once you get your bearings.

You start off with a machete and must explore and loot settlements and chests to find gear. Once you have a few kills under your belt you may buy items from the store which strictly uses in-game money, there are no microtransactions.

You will die often to begin with but with practice you can drop every dinosaur with a few arrows and then theres the other weaponry, which are all diverse and good for different purposes. Pistol, machete and .308 rifle are good for smaller dinosaurs, whilst Shotgun, .700 double rifle and .50 sniper rifle are good for big prey, like T-Rex.

Killing every dinosaur is rewarding not only mentally but earning XP and money too to level up and buy items. When you kill your first T-Rex alone or with others, it's a very good feeling, and leaves you wanting more.

Overall I recommend this game to those who are patient and can apperciate a good looking game, where stealth and aiming your shots plays a huge role. As I said before, if you are into dinosaurs in any way, shape or form then this is a must buy. Please don't let the bad reviews put you off, there has been significant patching of the issues mentioned in them. The game is very enjoyable as of writing this.

9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is in an really early state.Good points:
Huge and beautiful map but clearly empty
Dinosaur modelisation
GPS system useful and intelligent
Good sound design
Bad points:
No Stereo makes you walking around to search chest/dinosaur
Dinosaur animations jerky
Dinosaur AI hilarious
A lot of ergonomic simple things becoming complicated
Rate of loot/dinosaur totally random
Artefacts/No running bugs depend of your computer
20$ early access is expensive
Only 3 dinosaurs
Not enough interest (No craft, no build, no point, no special area...)You have to know what you buy.
I will change my recommendation. It depends of updates.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have to say I was fairly worried about getting an early access game; however, I am very relieved to say buying this was no mistake.  The entire time you are in game you are on edge waiting for what dinosaur might come around the corner or sneak up on you.  This game sort of draws you in and will not let you go.

There are a few things that are quite annoying, when someone begins to lose connection the entire game I suppose pauses for everyone.  When you spawn you could very well spawn right next to a Raptor or Big Rexy.

I have not played this game long, I feel I will enjoy it for quite some time, though I do feel as though after playing it for a day or so it might lose its replayability because killing three types of dinos can only be entertaining for so long.  An indepth story or more features would definitely help this game out a ton!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game has potential and i love theHunter original game, however at this point its not a good game its a how long untill you die game.  Graphics look great like the original, sounds are cool and imursive which is what you want.  The gameplay not so much.  You start off with just a bow and 5 arrows in a world that currently only has tricerotops which act like deer when you get close and tyranasaurus and raptors.  Now thats all cool and dandy but the fact your suppose to find better gear in this huge world with only 5 arrows to start and your surronded by these predators makes for very not fun gameplay.

No matter where you spawn there willl be either a raptor or trex near by, no joke.  also one major bug ive noticed is when you attack a raptor pack (yes i said pack they are never alone) if they kill you that same group will stalk right to you when you respawn. NO JOKE, try it attack one group die and start walking and you'll noticed there is a group stalking you.  If  you had better gear id accpet that but 5 arrows folks thats it. Also attacking is not easy you can shoot your 5 arrows into a raptor and he still will not go down, which make self deffense very hard to do when hes attacking.  And running away lol come on be realistic.

It has Potential but at this point its more frustrating then fun, i'm still giving it a positive review because i have high hopes for it, and i know what they did with the original hunter so *fingers crossed*
voteText: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Entered the game for the first time and decided to just run around to see a dino before playing seriously.

After about five minutes of running around picking up rocks and scanning piles of dino-poo, I finally heard something unusual and turned around to see the male Utahraptor I had been tracking sprinting right at me.  Took me multiple times to figure out how to fire my bow but after four arrows and me crying like a little girl I finally killed the damn thing with a sliver of my own health left.

...Except I wasn't expecting the female to be right around the corner.  I managed to duck into the roots of an old tree fast enough to avoid being detected right as it ran by.  After accepting that my pants would be forever soiled I decided to play it ballsy and take on another Utahraptor with only a single arrow.

Three minutes of getting myself lined up later, I finally took what I thought to be my last shot before dying a violent death... Except the raptor dropped almost instantly.  Shot through the heart and got an insta-kill.

I'm not even mad that my butt got torn off by a T-Rex several minutes later while trying to find more ammo.  Worth it.

Game needs some serious polishing still but shows a ton of promise for an early access game.  Would recommend.

reviewText: Great game, with a few very hindering bits. Hunting is fun and suspenseful. There is nothing like trying to make your way through a forest while avoiding a t-rex, or finally finding the right hardware to become the hunter. The recently added Quetzacoatlus (pterodactly like creature) are grossly imbalanced and really hurt the fun significantly. Standing anywhere but in the middle of a forest means you are prone to being swooped off the ground and dropped to you death. The other dinos are fairly well balanced, with the exception of a few glitchy bits, like t-rex's biting through trees to get you. Another HUGE issue I have with the game is the stamina system. There is a traditional bar that deplets when you use it, however, it depletes extraordinarily fast, and refills quite slowly. you can barely make it 15 feet before your out of stamina, and likely being eaten by a dino. It is almost inexcusable to be chased by a raptor for 15 feet, be out of stamina, and then basically watch as it attacks you while you slowly try to WALK away from it. In a dinosaur hunting game, mobility is key, and it is really lacking here. If they took out the Q's, fixed a few minor bugs, and made stamina much more balanced, this would be a 10/10 game. As it stands, I give it a solid 7.5/10, and worth a purchase if you can catch it on sale.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Hunter: Primal Early Access Review
Positives

- Dinosaur's are highly detailed,fitting Sound and movement animations ( since last patch)
-Terrain is absolutely beautiful (set to max resolution)
-The majority of the community is friendly, and willing to help out a hunter in need of assistance.
-The Terrain is large and comfortable size, your stamina recovery rate is just perfect to make sure you can run and keep an eye out for predators.
- Weapon sound and animation's are spot on
- gives you a customizable option to wear selected camo such as Merc Spec - Ops, Noble Gear, Settler gear etc.
They've included feathers on the dinosaurs (which personally i have really enjoyed as it gives them such a unique look like no other dinosaur game has done, like the Utahraptor has an amazing look thanks to the Feather pattern.

negatives
- Have encountered a few pesky,annoying bugs.
-If you fall in the water, you cant swim out and you have to helplessly watch yourself drown...
-Game has crashing issues, however they are working towards fixing that and so far there has been a drastic improvement.
-Some dinosaur spawn point's are glitched - Take for example i joined a game and had three T - Rex's in the area, I did not survive as expected.
-inventory space is quite small, hence you will have to be very careful as to what you keep in your inventory because take for example if a t rex is charging at you from a distance you will want to start shooting at it with your scope, but when he gets closer you would like to switch to iron sight but you may have a full inventory space so you would have had to drop it..
-Some dinosaurs get stuck in the terrain, which is rather unfortunate in my opinion.

My Summary


i am going to write from an honest point here, i think the game is absolutely brilliant, The Dev's love the community and are willing to help the community in any way. Playing with other hunters is a must do, because sometimes you can get yourself into a really sticky situation it's always best to have someone watch your back.Some situations can be so intense for example hiding under a bush when a T Rex is standing right next to you.

Or the absolutely wonderful feeling you get when you find a .700, or noble gear for example.Even walking halfway across the map to meet up with your fellow hunter just gives you this great feeling of relief and joy.

For an early access game, i say this is a MUST PLAY! so go on, get the game - support the devs they really do deserve the support!

Thank You

reviewText: I went into this game after watching Jacksepticeye play it and i had high hopes for it: a dangerous planet full of dinosaur life and you must hunt while scavenging for suplies and survivng. While it sounds good on paper and sounds like it would be like the iOS game, Carnivores, this game is sadly a tedious attempt at a great game. Where Carnivores had good hunting strategies, sudden death as always a fear, fast travel, and a way to find your prey, this game lacks most of the listed. It is merely a running simulator, where you can literally press Q to automatically walk. The hunting system in the game is interesting to say the least. If you pick up on your prey's trail, you can actually track them on your device through their footprints and whatnot. The area is pretty well designed to say the least, giving the impression of a vast, open, and terrifying open world, but that is not the case. There are hardly any dinosaurs and the combat is done so ♥♥♥♥ poor its nearly impossible to kill any of the dinos. Not to mention walking around waiting for something to happen can get pretty tedious after a while. All in all, i would not recomend spending your money on this game. If you want to, then by all means go for it. Its not a terible game, but it will become boring.
